Overall this is a nice beer with some good coffee character. But... I'm jut not sure, it's good but not amazing. The beer is showing oxidization and the complexity isn't quite there. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
One of my favorite brew of all time, maybe one of the greatest too! You have that Vietnamese coffee taste and hops ! My god, this is a must have !

Kaatuu lasiin sysimustana, öljyisenä, vaahto on maitosuklaan värinen, melko pieni, mutta jättää reunuksen. Haju on paahteinen, vahvan yrttinen ja kahvinen, joukossa on häivähdys salmiakkia. Maku on paahteisen kahvinen, yrttinen, joukossa on myös salmiakkia ja lakritsia. Suutuntuma on melko täyteläinen, hieman katkera. Kokonaisuutena Köpiksen reissun pahin pettymys (odotuksiin nähden siis). Aivan liian kahvinen meikäläisen makuun, koska en sitä juo. Muuten hieno olut kyseessä.
Poured from a 500ml bottle, huge thanks to dcschiller. Chocolate, dark stone fruits/prunes, coffee, some oxidized notes. The coffee is subtle. A great balanced stout.

Thick and oily with a creamy tan head. Tons of light coffee aroma with some dark fruitiness too. Creamy and smooth with fantastic coffee. Great weasel innards flavor. You can really taste the filthy asshole of a small beast. Ok not really but I am a sucker for this coffee and it works so well in this beer. Amazing brew.

2 year old bottle. Pours black with a medium head with a brownish colour. Very much chocolate in the aroma. Milk chocolate and some darker chocolte, roasted coffee, soy, vanilla. Really smooth taste, a lot of dark, bitter chocolate and a lot of coffee. The aftertaste is what its all about, wow!
The smell of this beer is damn near perfect. The taste is good, but doesnt live up to the smell.  Thats all Ive got time for now.
This is probably the thickest, darkest brew Ive had yet. Hesitant because of the process, but really fantastic. Very rich, chocolate/coffee finish.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2012 Bottle from somewhere in July 2010. Aroma and flavor of the best coffee Ive ever had...and, apparently, several cats (they also do this with elephants now). Anyway, excellent dark chocolate and molasses notes to pair with the Civet. Amazing, amazing beer. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2013 Bottle from Timfoolery on Christmas morning; minimal head, slight booziness, light coffee taste.  Encountered a strange gelatinous substance at the bottom of the bottle; which made the last few ounces undrinkable.

I was going in with huge expectations, think I like the cognac and calvados weasel more. Has great coffee and chocolate aromas. Taste is some really nice coffee, chocolate and has a decent roast. Still an excellent brew.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Had this beer at Mikkellers bar in Copenhagen. All I can say is WOW!!! By far the best beer I have had! The aroma, the taste, the oat, the coffee... It all just works!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours jet black. Aroma of molasses, figs and soy sauce. Taste of smooth biscuit, medium coffee in the middle, burnt toast, and a hint of dates. Medium body with a dry finish. Solid, but I had higher expectations.

[bottle--thanks, fonefan!]
pSweet Pumpernickel malt aroma up front with pine hops and some bitter and tangy espresso. Oily, thick black appearance under a light brown foam that does not last too long. Rich bitter and tangy (Belgian) chocolate flavour with bitter pine hops and brown-sugar sweetened coffee. Lots of vanilla and sweet pumpernickel too. Full body, moderate carbonation, lasting bitter chocolate finish.

Bottle from South Bay Drugs and Liquor: Created thick monstrous foam of tanned colored head while the liquid was as beautiful as black gold. In the aroma, a rich and robust scent of high quality coffee bean greets my nose, and I keep sniffing it like cocaine up a nostril. Aromas are mouth watering and it comes to no surprise you can practically smell the caffeine and a small trace of cocoa butter. The drink rewards my taste buds with a rich buttery and bitter flavor, and has a rich complex coffee bean with perfectly roasted malts. Some background of raw cocoa powder, chocolate and a scoop of Irish cream or perhaps even vanilla? Damn tasty stuff and I wish I could buy more bottles of this stuff.

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2016 Flaske, delt med Willy, batch 459 (brygget 07.10.09, best før 07.10.12.): en fantastisk aroma av mørkbrent kaffe, eksotiske og sjeldne kaffesorter jeg aldri har smakt, vanilje, og moccabønner spredte seg i rommet da flasken ble åpnet. En åpenbaring av fylde og balanse. Kanskje noe av det beste jeg har smakt, og med den lengste ettersmak man kan ønske seg. Drikkeglede som passet perfekt til Sibelius fiolinkonsert spilt Henning Kraggerud(med  Bournemouth SO dirigert av Bjarte Engeset): intensitet og nærhet i perfekt harmoni og teknisk helt uanstrengt. Versjonen komponert og gjennomført på Lervig står ikke tilbake for Sibelius. Et mesterbrygg fra Mikkeller og Mike Murphy.

Bottle from Felix, thanks for the trade!
Pours pitch black with a thin brown head.
Aroma has loads coffee and some bitter notes.
Taste has a coffee taste that sneaks up to you. Wham! What a coffee punch!
Coffee, bitter, roasted malt, huge amounts of chocolate and even more coffee. The chocolate and coffee taste alternates pretty much between each sip. Vinous notes. Where are the 10.9% alcohol? Not in the taste at all.
After taste is really long and chocolate bitter.
Full bodied, low carbonation.
Addicted to coffee and imperial stouts? This is for you!

Bought 2010 Alko Arkadia Helsinki.
After 2 years i finally enjoyed this one. 
Pours black with nice medium brown head. Aroma is roasted malts, coffee, some alcohol, dark chocolate. Flavor is roasted malts, espresso, chocolate and more coffee. Some alcohol and bittterich finish. Swell!

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2012 14.99 1pt .9fl oz bottle ordered from internet. Pours a dark caramel color with very little head. The aromas dont come off as your average coffee stout. There is more of an acidic quality here. Theres burnt malts malts, strong coffee, molasses, wood, chocolate, and sweet caramel under the other malts. Flavors of burnt malts, cocoa, coffee (which is not that strong here like in the nose ), and just a poof of hops underneath. Medium acidity, highly bitter with a sting of a bitter finish that lingers for quite some time,  medium sweet, and a velvety texture. The special coffee used doesnt add any more special flavors then most other coffee stout except it seems to be more bitter/ acidic and leave that bitter bite on the palate. A very good stout but a little over rated.  Would not buy again because of the rarety and price but glad I did get a bottle to sample. A rare treat indeed. Now at least I can say Ive tried some of the rarest coffee in the world. I just wont mention where or rather from what it comes from....
Huge coffee over big black beer.    Top notes slightly fruity, intense and perfumy.   top class beer, and a great extension of the Geek series.

June 23rd, 2010 - By this point (Summer of 2010) I had heard only faint whispers about Mikkeller. My local beer store guru held him in some kind of mystical reverence, and I had seen his names plastered across forum boards, but I didnt quite understand what the fuss was about. Seeking to remedy that and my sobriety, I sampled the Beer Geek Brunch Weasel. It wears no hat, but a crown, producing very little head save for a halo of medium brown lacing around the edges of the opal black body. The smell is dark and rich, like a clod of deep, rich earth, with an oily smell too. Fresh yams and molasses and brown sugar make my stomach stir, and an edge of bitter vegetables reminds me that balance in beer and in food groups is essential. The taste mirrors the aroma - a welcome reflection. New in the flavor is a considerable pour of alcohol and a coffee bitterness to pair off again the abysmal sugars. Amongst the dark chocolate flavors, burnt and chipped sugars and molasses and harsh dark chocolate bitterness is plenty of strength and burly flavors. What I dont see is elegance, however, but a dancing troupe of elephants, crushing everything underfoot. If thats your thing, the Mikkeller Beer Geek Brunch Weasel is a top-notch brew, but I find it a little heavy handed for my taste.

A fatty black one with a thin Brown head. Roasted different malts in aroma and flavour. Not my up of tea

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from 8.5 oz bottle.  The color is black as the night with no head. The nose has a strong coffee aroma.  The taste is also of coffee with pronounced sugar tones.  Overall a very pleasing drink.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours dark with no head
Aromas of coffee, black malts. Almost syrupy aroma.
High bitterness, shit loads of coffee, chocolate and vanilla
Very good!
bottle. pour is redish brown with no head. aroma is of slight sour coffee and coco. taste is like bitter baking chocolate and coffee possible infection?
22oz bottle, pours dark brownish black. Aroma of coffee and roastiness. The taste is like the aroma, coffee and roasted malt. It actually got better as it warmed, overall, this was a great beer.

Pours a two finger brown head that fades slowly leaving a good lace.  Totally black color, some yeast (I hope thats what it is) left in bottle.  Good carbonation and heavy bodied.  Roasted coffee nose and flavor is roasted coffee and some malty sweetness, seems like a decent imp oatmeal stout without detecting any weasel turds but then I always take a pass when the weasel turds are passed around so I dont know what they taste like. Expensive at $15.80 for a 500ml bottle from Tullys Beer and Wine Wells, ME.

Used oil pour.  Viscous, oily, black as tar. This beer just screams MORE. More coffee, more alcohol, more hops, more malt.  I can already tell that this is going to be a beast of a beer.  Aromas of expresso, roasted malts, slight whiff of alcohol.  Tate is exquisite... High end roasted coffee, combined with a select handful of hops and a dash of soy sauce.  Really fucken good.  Alcohol hits hard, especially on an empty stomach.  Got buzzed quick.
From the bottle, nearly black pour with reddish brown head.  Aroma is of coffee and roast with a tiny bit of berries, taste adds some chocolate to the table and makes this a very enjoyable brew.
A very impressing brew! When I translated the Danish comment on the bottle, my wife suddenly lost her appetite, though :p
Who would have ever thought weasel feces could possibly taste so damn good?

Bottle, 50cl - Opaque black beer with a brown head. Aroma is malty with notes of nuts, coffee, burnt sugar, chocolate and dark berries. Flavor is malty with notes of coffee, espresso, chocolate, woody, soy sauce and tobacco. Lovely aftertaste, slightly warming alcohol touch. Excellent beer.
Beautiful pour, jet black with a thick brown head. Cherry, slightly roasty, vaguely musty aroma. Deliciously thick, creamy mouthfeel. Rich choclatey, cherry taste, slight alcohol edge.

From a bottle drank in Feb 12.

Pours a jet black colour with a good finger of creamy brown head that begins to subside and thin out after a few minutes.

Surprised at the lack of aroma for such a strong, bold beer ! Roasted malt, slightly burnt sugar, coffee and tar. Dont get me wrong there are plenty of smells going off here, just not as big and brassy as Id have liked! (more smells now that the beer has warmed a little, more chocolate, stronger coffee aroma and a little alcohol)

The taste is a clear cut 2 way thing for me and no need to think too deeply and list 101 ingredients. First a wonderful bittersweet coffee flavour hits your palate, this then gives way to a real kick of alcohol in the aftertaste. I prefer the former to the latter as it is a little bit too much alcohol for me in the aftertaste. (the alcohol aftertaste is less harsh when the beer has warmed and more enjoyable)

Mouthfeel is spot on for a beer of this ilk, slick, oily and just the right level of carbonation. (continues to provide a good MF)

Overall a very good beer, but I think I expected a little more. I was expecting a stronger aroma and the alcohol aftertaste could have been better disguised, it strips away the wonderful coffee flavour a little too much and too quickly for my liking. Would definately have again though just for that first coffee hit on the palate! (it definately improved when warmed a little) Veering towards world class but not quite there IMHO!
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: On tap @ Melkebaren, Sandnes. Pours pitch black, with a creamy, lightly coloured head. Aroma is sweet, with leather and tobacco, as well as coffee, liquorice, chocolate and some toffee. Body is very full, with an oily texture and almost no carbonation. Flavour is sweet, with lightly burned notes. Heres coffee, dark fruits and syrup, with a nice long burned bitter finish of coffee and tobacco.

11oz. bottle from Minks, Marietta ----> snifter.  Pours deeeeep black with no head at all and no lacing.  Aroma is black coffee and red wine. Taste is sweet black coffee, vanilla, and hazelnut.  Palate is everything a stout be, thick and vicious.  Such a wonderful stout.
Dough, earthy, cooked vegetables, citrus, basement aromas, cheese, cooked vegetables, cereal, toast
From tap. Black with medium lacking brown head. Aroma has burned malt and sweet vanilla. Flavour has thick burned coffe, chocolate and sweet malt. Light bitter finish. Very drinkable style.

GREAT BEER! One of the best beers i have ever had. Had it from tap at Melkebaren i Sandnes (Norway). Black and oily apearance, with a nice coffe/liquorice smell. Tasted just as delicious as the smell, even though i knew i was drinking shit.. ;-)

16 oz bottle from Ottos in the Falls shared with ck1. Pours a foamy dark, dark brown with a chocolate milk head. Leaves nice lacing throughout the glass. Aroma has super bittersweet bakers chocolate and roasted malts - thats it, but, boy, that was enough. Lovely! Taste is of syrupy sweet chocolate, caramel malts, expresso, chocolate liquor. Quite sweet, but with a lot of enduring body and depth. Finishes sweetly bitter and about medium length.  A really, really nice dessert brew.
Deep black, modest but enduring head formation. Rich wine and burnt licorice aroma. Burnt chocolate flavor, creamy with alcohol finish. Some dry graininess offers good compliment.

Bottle 500ml.
Pours black with brown head, diminishing. Nice lacing. Aroma is of coffee, roasted malt, alcohol. Taste is of coffee, roasted malt, chocolate, bitterness, alcohol (warming), sweetness. Overall: creamy/oily mouthfeel. Bitter finish. Very good beer.

As a pour it it is black as engine oil and about as thick. There was no head really and seems like there is no carbonation. I get strong smell of chocolate and coffee. The taste is chocolate for sure and alotta coffee.  Bitter on the backside and aftertaste. Hint of oatmeal in the aftertaste. It is very full bodied almost like chocolate was melted and poured into a glass. Not a bad brew a bit spendy but you get what u pay for.

Tried @ Grain Cru - Roll Out the Barrels, Belgian Beer Café.Black as midnight. Compact, tight and mostly lasting brownish crown. Very husky is the aroma; lots of smoke, bonfire ash, tar, heavily roasted coffee beans and an undeniable and well pronounced note of aniseed. A good lot of medicinal alcohol in there also that really tickles the nose. Noticeable aniseed on the palate too reminiscent of sarsparilla with its subtle sweetness. Smooth, oily and slightly viscous body, not big but filling. Chocolate icecream and bitter and sharp roasted coffee bean fuels the rest. The alcohol soothing, warming and medicinal in the heavily smoky, ashen finish. Excellent length. A little residual chocolate malt sweetness on the tongue fades the smoke and anise between sips. Didnt take me as anything special given the civet-cats arse droppings hype. Could have done away with that altogether. Not bad! (50cL, 2011, Cellarbrations Carlisle)

Style et résumé: Imperial Oatmeal Stout au café de civet. 
Comment: Bouteille de 500ml batch 697 un gros merci à Slovaksniper. 
Description: Bière noire opaque avec une superbe tête de mousse crémeuse. Le nez est de grain rôti, de café, et de cacao en poudre. Lalcool semble bien dissimulé. En bouche le liquide a une superbe texture. À prime abord lamertume des grains détonne, ça mord en fin de bouche. Heureusement lensemble est plus harmonieux avec le temps. La finale est longue et savoureuse. Une bonne bière mais jai préféré la version en baril de bourbon. 
Note:   7+/10

50cl bottle. Pours opaque black with a lovely crema head. The nose has seriously intense coffee, with earthy and chocolate notes. The taste has more intense and bitter coffee with a long dry coffee finish. The palate is rich, full in texture with a long dry but elegant finish. Overall, great beer.

No clue how old this is, but it was a bit dusty. 500 ml bottle into an over sized wine glass.

A - Pitch black body lets zero light through. 2 finger high mocha head forms and settles to a nice bubbly cap. Great lacing and retention and some alcohol legs produced after swirling.

S - Ive never had civet coffee before so Im a bit inexperienced in its nuances, but the coffee aroma here is roasty but not bitter. Its hard to explain. Very sweet yet roasty coffee and malts which works great against the deep vanilla and dark chocolate notes. Really unique and fantastic.

T - Just as extraordinary as the nose. Sweet vanilla and dark chocolate followed by lightly roasty yet sweetened coffee notes. There is some slightly vinous and fruity red wine notes towards the finish as well. Syrupy and coating, with low carbonation.

O - Im not a Mikkeller fan at all. After trying three of the B/A black hole beers I gave up on buying there stuff. This bottle was given to me so I went into it rather unbiased of its price tag. But holy crap has my image of them changed. This is a phenomenal stout. I think I prefer BCBCS a bit more in terms of coffee stouts, but this is a huge achievement, I though it was going to beer an average gimmicky beer using one of the most expensive coffee beans, buts its just so damn delicious. Kudos Mikkeller!

A: Deep black, with a thick beige crema head. Soda pop effervescence.

S: Wonderful scents of gourmet coffee and roasted malts.

T: World class. This is one of my favorite beers of all time. I have had this beer several times now, and its blown me away every time. Its slightly sweet, and the coffee is superb (no matter where it came from). The delicious oatmeal gives the beer a crispness that makes it even tastier and more drinkable. This is a desert island beer for me.

M: Perfect carbonation and buttery smooth.

D: Truly fantastic beer. Id drink this anytime.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2013 Pours pitch black with nice dark tan head that lingers nicely.  Big lacing on the glass.  Aroma is rich chocolate and coffee, well balanced.  Also getting a little grassy hops.  Taste is both sweet and bitter, nicely balanced again.  Incredibly smooth in the finish with a very slight alcohol burn.  The chocolate and coffee flavors linger on the tongue a while.  Hard to rate this beer.  I really enjoyed getting to drink this finally.  While it is tasty and very smooth, nothing really stood out to me or excited me.  This is a very good imperial stout but Ive had many better.  Re-rate 12/3/13 - Huge coffee aroma mixed with some rich milk chocolate.  Taste is just packed with fresh coffee with milk chocolate and fudge too.  Super creamy and fairly thick body.  This stuff is awesome and better than I remember the first time.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2013 Bottle from Great Grog who have a righteously vast selection from this brewery...
Great name and great label. Weasel shit coffee huh? That takes some beatin. 
Black as night w/ thin tan head. A-rising up outta the blackness is boozy vanilla and malty coffee. In the mouth there was an unguent velvet power with pungent floral kick to ass near end. Wowser yes sir.

Bottle 500 ml. Pitch black with a medium fully diminishing brown head. Aroma of bitter chocolate, roasted malt, coffee, dark fruits and slight vanilla notes. Taste of coffee, roasted malt and bitter chocolate. Mouthfeel is thick and creamy but leaves the palate dry (roasted bitterness). Good balance between sweetness and bitterness. Very good beer but still a bit under my expectation (who where pretty high). I think I will need to re-taste.

Pours dark brown, medium dissipating head.  Aroma of sweet malt, chocolate, toast, coffee, banana? Tastes smooth, burnt tips, coffee, dark chocolate. 


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
UPDATED: JUL 5, 2012 best beer ive had. perfect mouthfeel, thick and syrupy. perfectly balanced chocolate coffee and booze flavours. a treasure

UPDATED: APR 20, 2014 Pours black with tan head aromas of heavy roast and coffee. The taste is delicious, rich and bright on the coffee in the foreground. This gives the best coffee stouts a run for their money. The grain is smooth and easy to get around with a large flavor of barley and prevalent oats with a dense body for strength. Some bitterness from the grain comes in with a noticeable green hop flavor. The alcohol is hardly apparent. The beer has a lightly fruity yeast that flows well with the coffee. This tastes like coffee with some grainy sweetness, really good stuff if you like heavily roasted things. Can?t say enough, this is a great oatmeal stout.
i think there is some hype around this beer, it is very good, a little sweet. coffee has some nice flavors, it is a good beer but ale smith speedway stout i think is the best example of this style

Un liquide bien épais qui tombe avec lourdeur dans mon verre de 50 Cl.  Une large tête mousseuse pratiquement rousse.  De richissimes effluves de café qui se choquent à des tremblements chocolatés et des tsunamis de caramel foncé.  Des hallucinations de fût, de fumée et de cerises bien noires qui viennent me hanter à tout instant.  Où est lalcool?  Sans doute anéanti par ce terrifiant cocktail malté.  Les houblons apparaissent de façon définitive en bouche.  Ils enrobent les grains de café et les grains fortement rôtis qui tapissent une extravagante douceur maltée sur mes papilles.  Des flaveurs  brutales mais aussi douces.   Une cohésion des saveurs vraiment intéressante.  Une impression au palais qui se renforce au fil de la dégustation.  Un corps solidement musclé dans lequel sinfiltre des bulles plutôt molles.  Une texture plantureuse qui nhésite jamais à jouer la carte de la souplesse.  Une finale dans laquelle participe des notes amères de houblons et des notes amères de torréfaction qui sont vivement entrecoupés par les chauds murmures dun alcool subversif.  Véritablement une  bête féroce qui finit bien par ronronner dans le fond de mes entrailles.  Merci à tom10101 pour la bouteille.
Bottles, many times. Black pour with some mocha head. Coffee notes are most obvious, chocolate, alcohol, roast. Extreme portions, careful balance. World class.
Lots of coffee, which adds a nice extra touch to the otherwise tasty flavours of chocolate, molasses and vanilla.

Aged bottle, purchased from Premier a while back.  Black body, great craggy dark tan head.  Nose is bitter cocoa, alcohol, dark fruit skin, coffee, sweet malt.  Flavor follows with big dark chocolate dominating, alcohol, burnt coffee, fruit skin & cocoa.  Nice mouthfeel, dry finish.

Black thick tan head. Big oaky vanilla coffee aroma, smooth, coco, huge body. Oaky, bit boozey, Sweet roasty finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours deep oily black with a slight but dark head and excellent lacing.  Great coffee aroma with hints of nut, molasses and maple.  Flavors of coffee and a touch of dark fruit.  Full, creamy body with slight carbonation.

A great aroma. Not overpowering. Its just right. Beautiful roasted notes. The weasel also has amazing flavor that matches its scent. The stout does not impact the palate. Give it two minutes and its gone. After you drink this you will sense that all the flavor will remain for awhile but it does not. Yet I miss the after taste and I desire another sip. A must try.

500 ml bottle at Chez Moeder Lambic Fontainas. Pours pitch black with light marron head. Intense aroma of ceffe and dark chocolate with notes of dates, prunes and some honey. Rich body, slight carobnation and smooth balance. Woow, what an intensive taste - dark dark chocolate, some liquorice, Incredible beer.

Poured into a snifter.  Black with a thin, oily looking dark brown head.  Aroma is coffee, sweet and chocolatey with dark fruit, some nuttiness, some nice roasted character, and some alcohol.  Flavor is quite complex as well - roasty and chocolatey with coffee, some dark fruity notes and alcohol.  Full bodied with an oily mouthfeel and a long dry finish.  Overall this was an excellent imperial stout that begs to be sipped.  If this is your brunch you should be off to a great day, but this also makes a great dessert beer, which is how Im enjoying it (because I was too impatient to wait for a brunch opportunity).

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2015 Got the pleasure of drinking this monster again. Thanks to my man Vestergaard for bringing this! Pours black with a dark espresso brown head. Easy 5! Aroma is the sickest coffee ever. simple as that. Dark sweet characteristic fruits, espresso, dark rich chocolate, fruity coffee, brown sugar, fresh vanilla, roasted/burned malts and a bit of liquorice. Taste is sick coffee again. Hard roasted malts, vanilla, dark sweet fruits, brown sugar, espresso, liquorice, dryish roasted bitterness and rich chocolate. The balance is killing me. This is good!

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2012 Great beer. Pitch black, brown head, though very little. Semi sweet chocolate on the nose. Dark chocolate, coffee, a bit of smokiness, and whiskey. Bitter finish from the coffee. Tip: let this one breathe a bit. Overall, fantastic beer but I still prefer speedway stout.

Oh god. The aroma contains so much madly delicious coffee. Rather prominent chocolate as well. The taste is pretty much alike, but with figs, dades, plenty of vanilla and brown sugar as well. Sticky and delicious. Lovely balance and so much luxury. Ima buy one more now.
Delad flaska med några vänner På Besök i Malmö. Riktigt god. Kaffesmaken är frisk, krämig och kraftig på ett utsökt sätt.
Smellssss. Reallllyyy good.  Cognac.  YES.  Pours coffee black with a minuscule tan head.  Tastes chocolatey with a warming alcohol taste at the end.  A very very good brew.

Poured into a ccb snifter. Jet black with no head and a thin ring around the glass. Aroma of coffee and chocolate, rich chocolate. Taste follows the nose, chocolate cake or chocolate fudge. Very chewy. Great beer, there is a lot going on, very different from other coffee stouts and I like it.

bottle from Capones. Pours a beautiful jet black with frothy head that fades. nose is aromatic coffee, coco nibs and dark choolate, first sip is deep roasted flavors with a rich coffe flavor, black strap molasses.  finish is lingering coffee and bittersweet chocolate. great beer

Bottle at Volo some time back. Pours opaque black with decent tan head and lace. Unique aromas of mocha, pine, toast, choc and a refined coffee bean note. Complex medium-high body, smooth silky goodness with a dark roast finish, acrid oatmeal mixed with the light sweetness and complexity of the beans and malt. Brilliant beer.

A litros.Espesa stout con espuma marron rojiza,que aprece una vez se asienta en el vaso.Aromas a chocolate,cafe.....mmmmmmmmmmmm
woooow,De lo mejor en stouts.Muy bien balanceada.Un buen alimento.
This is just incredible.  Mouth feel is velvety.  Dark chocolate malt flavor.  The coffee flavor was very smooth with almost no bitterness.  This might be my favorite stout.

Love this beer. Nose is rich and full of bitter coffee. The taste is similar and has and exceptional balance of malt and coffee with just a bit of coffee. WIsh it was more available and not so damn expensive...

Refrigerated 0.5 L brown bottle set on the counter for a bit.  Pours opaque black with small dark brown highlight and small light brown head that dissapates a fair amount.  Some small lacing, thick body, smooth texture, low carbonation, and sweet roasted malt aroma.  Taste is roasted malt, chocolate, some coffee, hint of burnt malt, hint of vanilla, hint of licorice, and light dry bitter finish.  Nice balance of malt and hops, warming alcohol which is well covered, and overall great beer.

Bottle at Dans, courtesy of Aaron. Thanks man! Poured an opaque brown with a small chocolate head. Tobacco, molasses, coffee, syrup, and cocoa in the aroma. Taste is deep chocolate and coffee, espresso, toffee, and light tobacco with a lingering bitter aftertaste. Mouthfeel is mouth-coating and sticky with medium carbonation and light lacing. Pretty smooth with deep chocolate, lingering acid and espresso. Delicious.

Wow. One of the best beers that I have tried. Full of malt and coffee flavour, low carbonation, a well balanced stout.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Very dark pour.  Big espresso head.  Some lacing.  Aroma of rich dark coffee.  Mouth is super chewy and heavy.  Alcohol is well hidden.  Taste is very balanced.  Finishes like a cup of coffee.  Very very tasty.

I honestly do not know why I do not buy more of this beer. Simply stunning beer. 
Lots of coffee, oat, and chocolate. quite dry finish but very coating in the front of palate. Low carbonation and heavy feel. Stunning beer

I needed something special for my 400th rating and beer made with coffee beans that came out of a weasels ass seemed appropriate.  Strong dark roasted coffee/malt aromas coming off an opaque black body topped with a creamy light brown head.  This has to be one of the blackest beers Ive ever had.  Even under a bright halogen light I see absolutely nothing coming through and even around the bottom edge of the glass where theres usually at least some color I can only see the slightest sliver of ruby that would be completely unnoticeable otherwise.   Rich dark and bittersweet chocolate flavors as well as espresso roll across the tongue followed by an acrid bitterness that is most likely from the coffee and dark roasted malt.  This would be tough to drink except for the beautifully balanced black strap molasses sweetness that wraps up the bitter flavors and carries them away.   Theres a creamy feel to this thats simultaneously cut by the dry, woody roasted bitterness.  Theres also an earthiness to this thats hard to describe except as "clean dirt".   Theres some soy sauce and vanilla in there too, but theyre muted by the heavy chocolate/coffee presence.  Left behind are the tongue scrapping roasted bitterness and semi-sweet chocolate flavors.   Theres a lot going on here (not least of which is the almost 11% ABV that doesnt bite like youd expect), but theres a balance between all these massive aromas and flavors that holds this together and makes it a great, memorable beer.

amateur review incoming!

Appearance: black and brown with a dark brown translucent edge. Little bit of head that dissipated nicely into the dark pool.

Smell: coffee and stouty malty goodness

Taste: rich coffee and yes, the oatmeal is present. The hops come through as does the malt and it winds up just a well-done good feeling taste. Little hint of alcohol on the aftertaste keeps this from a 5.0

Mouthfeel: Brown with a nice body. Yeah.

Drinkability: the aftertaste and the high abv stop it from perfection but on taste smell and mouthfeel alone this hits as one of the best Ive had.

Three cheers!!

Bottle.  Pitch black with a thin frothy brown head.  Aroma of milk chocolate, coffee, roasted/burnt malts, alcohol.  Taste is heavy coffee, with some cocoa/milk chocolate.  Mild-medium sweet with a nice, strong roasted bitterness.  Finish is roasted bitter.  Medium-full bodied, very very smooth, creamy, with soft carbonation.

Bottle in celebration of Chelseas glorious progression to the Champions League Final. This pours a thick, heavy deep brown with a tiny, tight tan head that quickly disappears. The nose is mellow milk chocolate and sweet coffee. Vanilla coated lightly roasted cocoa beans. Some maple syrup. The taste is smooth thick chocolate syrup and very mellow coffee. Powdered milk. The finishing flavor is fragrant roasted wood and caramel. Lightly bitter and dry, despite the rich flavors. The acidity that you usually get from coffee drinks is really reduced here, leaving a really pleasant, subtle sipper. Full bodied, thick and viscous. Overall, a very nice beer indeed enjoyed on a great occasion.

500 ml. bottle, batch # 588, brought to celebrate my rating # 500! Poured in to a snifter. Pitch black colour with a small, dense, tanned head, that fades to a thin ring around the edges of the glass. Very rich and full aroma with lots of coffee, licorice and roasted malts. Also hints of vanilla and smoke. Light bitter taste (with lots and lots of good stuff...). Excellent palate for a stout: Full body, and a thick, creamy texture. Finishes powerful and long lasting with lots of coffee, licorice, vanilla and roasted malts. No sign of the alcohol. Excellent experience, and clearly one of the best beers, I´d ever had.
The perfect coffee-beeer? Pours dense black with a lovely mocca 2. finger head that lasts. Taste is full: roast, coffee (loads), dark fruits and dry chocolate. Creamy! Good stuff!
Just the smoothest, best tasting coffeeish stout I have had not as complex as my favorites, but so easy drinking, and the story of how its made doesnt hurt.

A black beer with a dense, beautiful, creamy and dark brown head. Aroma is great, roastiness, liquirice, syrup like sweetness, some coffee and dark fruits. Full bodied, very smooth to drink, not sticky, enjoyable. Taste is roasted, black coffee, salt liquirice, dry herbs and old, concentrated coffee in the aftertaste. Blessed words are said, but this beer earns them all, very balanced and complex, coffee and roasted IS .

Bottle with SED and KMD. Treacle texture, jet black with a film of tan head. Aroma is fruit and lots of coffee. Lots going on here but it all comes back to heavy coffee. Wouldn't be something I would run back to.

(bottle 05/04-2012) low dark brown head, pitch black color,slightly roasted intense coffee aroma, soft co2, very smooth taste, creamy taste, coffee taste. Label hard to read, batch #697, brewed 19.09.2011.

Pours a nice jet black with minimal head and some lacing. Aromas of chocolate and coffee. Tastes like it smells, fantastic flavors of bitter sweet chocolate and smooth coffee. Very smooth and silky on my tounge, great beer!

I dont know whether Im rating the beer or the coffee. What a sensational brew (in both senses). Strong smell of dark chocolatey coffee. The taste is deliciously bittersweet coffee. Truly sensational beer from easily the best brewery on the planet. Keep it up Mikkeller!

Viscous jet black body with a dark brown head. Strong wine aroma with alcoholic notes. Very distinct coffee, some vanilla, chocolate, rye bread and wood. No sign of poop :) Licorice and more coffee in the after taste.

500 ml bottle bought @ Ølbutikken. Pours oily black with a big creamy brownish gray head that slowly dissipates while leaving some nice looking lacing on the glass. Smell is sweet, intense and full bodied with roasted malts, quality coffee, chocolate, vanilla, honey, wood and alcohol. Taste is sweet, bitter and tiny sour with tons of quality coffee, roasted malts, bitter chocolate, raisins, dark bread, vanilla, liquorice, wood, oats, resin and warming alcohol. Mouthfeel is creamy, silky and full bodied. Finish is tiny sweet, bitter and dry with coffee, roasted malts, bitter chocolate, cocoa and liquorice. Incredibly smooth, balanced and good.
thicker black pour than regular geek breakfast. Dark caramel head, lots more coffee aroma. Flavor is much more coffee than oatmeal, lots of dark roasty flavors. Delightful beer.
0.5l - Oily appearance, so viscous. Nearly no carbonation. Tastes like a perfect cup of coffee with astringent booze finish. Nothing I would change.

Pours tar black with a tan head.  Aroma of coffee, roasted malt, chocolate, oats, and hops.  Flavor of coffee, oatmeal, roasted malt, hops, and a surprising coffee ending.  Decent body.  Really nice beer!

50 cl bottle @ home. Pours jet black with small khaki head that fades pretty quickly leaving virtually no lace. Aroma is spicy and peppery coffee, a little vanilla, dark chocolate, liquorice, and a slight hint of smoke. Taste is very much like the aroma with a slightly bitter finish.
UPDATED: MAR 15, 2013 Cerveza negra, aromas torrefactos y a café. Sabor a caf, cacao y maltas tostadas, Exquisita.

Bottle, shared. Pours motor oil black, with pretty vigorous, fluffy brown head that reduces to about half a finger, eventually. Massive, spicy coffee on the nose, along with bits of milk chocolate, dark chocolate, slight vanilla and earthy nuttiness. Again, big exotic coffees dominate the taste, with more chocolate and a more pronounced version of the nuttiness. Warming alcohol astringency. Long, scorched finish. A slow sipper, but so good.

On tap. Pours a black color with almost no head. Great lacing and alcohol lags on the glass. Aroma is roasted malts, coffee and bourbon. Taste is bold and bitter with coffee, bourbon and woody roasted notes. Almost full body and soft carbonation. Overall, interesting for sure and well made, but Id have preferred some more coffee on the nose.

From notes.  First reviewed 4/6/2011.  Served on tap at Local Option. From notes.

The appearance is nearly black, with a very pleasant creamy brown head. Although it does not exhibit great retention, there is some lace down the glass.

This has a very interesting aroma. Roasted malt, chocolate, and coffee are the most dominant. The unique coffee flavor is from the ca phe chon coffee, I imagine.

The first sip is a bit of a leap of faith for me, just because I know the ingredients. There is a very robust and unique coffee (weasel poop) flavor, with a lingering bitterness. Roasted malt, chocolate, a little vanilla, and more coffee in the finish.

The mouthfeel is smooth and very creamy, with medium carbonation, and a medium body. It is actually a little bit dry, which surprised me, but it was not off-putting.

I am over my fear of the Weasel, and I would definitely drink this again. The best part about this beer is tricking unsuspecting friends into trying a sip and then telling them about the civet coffee.
Bottle. Very lively upon opening. Big head with a full black body. Not as powerful as I expected but still pretty impressive.

Enjoyed out of the bottle and into a pint glass. This is tailor-made FOR COFFEE FANATICS. I am a major coffee addict so this one hit me the right way just from the initial smell out of the bottle as it was being poured. Its as close to perfection as a coffee stout can get. Just as Mikkeller does with all of his products, this one is brewed with only the finest, most expensive coffee beans and aged for a considerable amount of time before it finds its way to the shelves of your favorite liquor stores. An incredibly powerful drink that will floor you with its coffee intensity, this is not for the faint of coffee hearts. Fantastic.
UPDATED: APR 1, 2014 Café, tabac, chocolat et une touche de fumé infuse un corps somptueux et riche. Amertume torréfié en finale. Tapisse le palais merveilleusement.

Pour so thick and oily that it took a violent pour to build a decent head. Smells of smoke, wood, and intense dark roast coffee. Super intense and honestly a little much. Body isnt as heavy as I thought it would be from the pour. Carb is pretty low. Flavor is much smoother than the aroma as the bitter coffee and roasty malt blend nicely. Nice finish.
SMÖF 2011. Black beer with a beige head. Coffee vanilla aroma. Coffee and vanilla with some cream notes flavour.
A: sweetness ,coffee, toasty, toffee creaminess. T: dry malt sweetening to a caramel, F: sweet toffee, drying to a toasty, coffee ffinish.

Pours deep balck with some brown unsignificant foam traces.
It first smells like a strong barrel aged Shirae from Cote Rotie or Barrossa Valley: black olives, liquorice ... then all its beer dimension comes in mouth: caramelized plum, coffee, chocolate, zan. Is it a black Barley wine? An imperial stout? Smokey aftertsate.
Anyway its something really powerful!
Im gonna make a side-b-side tasting with De Molen Kopi Loewak this week. Then Ill know wich Wiesel Coffee brewed beer I prefer.

12 oz bottle pours black with a light brown head.  Aroma was coffee, with some vanilla, and molasses.  Tasted great, hit upfront with some coffee bitterness, which gives way to some lighter vanilla and cream flavors.

500ml bottle pours black in color with a 2 finger beige head that retains quite well and leaves some pleasant lacing on the glass.  Aroma is dark roasted malts and coffee and mild hops.  Taste is roasted malt and coffee bitterness with some chocolate malty sweetness and a mild hoppy bitter finish.  Flavors are very well balanced.  Heavy body and decent carbonation.  One of the best imperial stouts I have sampled to date.  Just outstanding.

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2012 A - pours slow and slick like motor oil. Deep opaque brown with very high chocolate brown head that dissipates. S - strong alcohol aroma when first poured, but goes away after a bit. Strong dark chocolate, nutty aroma toffee, bourbon and wood. Very nice string yet complex aromas. M - lighter than I expected. Medium body, very drinkable. Lingering drier ending. Slightly sweet syrupy throughout, but just right, not too sweet. T - coffee, bittersweet chocolate on the nose. Light sutble and good coffee & bitterness and smoke on the palate. You can taste the fact the itÃÂ¢Ã¢âÂ¬Ã¢âÂ¢s good coffee. Lingering chocolate, caramel and quiet dry bitter spice end. O - very good coffee stout, chocolaty coffee and very little hint of the 10%. Drinkable and really good. 8+

Let me get this out of the way right now: This may be one of the best beers i have ever had on tap. Roasted malty aroma. Coffee, fresh bread and toffee. The aroma carries on into the mouth. A real heavy, intense and complex explosion of chocolate, pastry, salt and roasted malts. The aftertaste is so good, you become reluctant to have another sip, in fear of missing something. It is really a fantastic imperial stout.
Dark Imperial Stout with tan head, nice and viscous with lots of coffee aroma and flavour. Initially very bitter with a lovely smiley after taste.

Decided to pull this one out of the cellar after two years to see how it is holding up.

A - Pours jet black with a small film of tan head, dissipating down to a light film, leaving no lace at all down the glass.

S - Smells of rich coffee, chocolate, dark roasted malt, charred wood and some warm alcohol. 

T - Starts off with a ton of slightly bitter dark roasted coffee slowly giving way to hints of chocolate, molasses, dark roasted malt and some charred wood. The booze only grows as it sits in the glass. Finish is a mix of light sweetness and warm booze, lingering on the pallet for some time.

M - Heavy body and flavor with moderate carbonation. Thick, slightly boozy feel. Kinda tastes like chocolate pudding.

O - I rather enjoyed this one, minus all the sludge at the bottom of the bottle. It had quite a bit of flavor and was fairly easy to drink, it did get a little boozy as it warmed up.

Pours almost jet black with a dark tan one finger head.Aroma is of sweet coffee beans and chocolate.Taste begins sweet like iced coffee almost with a malty backbone.Not as heavy or thick as I was expecting and has a lighter mouthfeel than some other coffee stouts I have had.Finishes with a slight alchohol bite but nothing too bad considering the abv.Overall this is a really good coffee stout and is fairly balanced comapred to some I have had.Definately will try this again.
Hoppy and boozy aroma.  Great mouth feel.  Coffee is very present, as is the alcohol.  Not as amazing as I was hoping for, but very very good.

Bottle from Savvy1982. Thanks Kyle!! About a 2 year old bottle by now. Pours out solid black with huge mocha head. Head stays about a finger and a half after a few minutes. I have never smelled so much chocolate in a beer before. Awesome. Earthy notes and coffee in the aroma as well. Some espresso and burnt coffee in the first sip. Digging deeper I find some roasty malts and plenty of dry bitterness. Very good.

I drank the whole bottle,(nothing new).  Black with small tan head.  A malty chocolate and coffee nose, of equal parts, with a background of hops.  Silky smooth medium palate.  Tastes of coffee, chocolate milk, licorice, with a mild sweetness, and again with a hoppy background.  Well balanced at this point. The finish however is astringent and dry, and it lasts forever.  This could be good and bad.  This is a special beer, ($15.00) and Im really enjoying it,

Bottle 50 cl from erzbierschof.ch. Opaque black beer, brown head which adheres a little to the glass. Aromas of macha, dark chocolate, licorice, strong roasted and note of tar. The taste is intense and roasted, black coffee, licorice.molasses. The sturdy and strong malt takes all the place. Earthy beer but intense, acidity of dark fruits, notes of toast. Full body and velvety texture. The bitter of roasted and hops embrace with an alcoholic touch at the end of sips.

This is so delicious! The aroma is like sniffing a block of milk chocolate. It is thick, luscious and oily on the palate and tastes of roasted oats, coffee and vanilla. It is a perfectly balanced beer that makes me happy with every sip. Like a cool breeze on a summer day...it makes you smile. Bravo.
The best shit Ive ever tasted.. literally. . Made from weasel droppings. Flavor and aroma is coffee grinds and toasted malts. Very malty and balanced.
Bottle. Pours dark black with an extremely creamy tan head. Aroma of malt, coffee, chocolate. Flavour is sweet, with lots of malt and some hops.  Exceptional.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2012 Out the bottle. Dark brown head. Slight coffee on the nose.Smooth coffee flavor with hints of cocoa. Not too much heat. Robust without being overpowering. Best shitty beer I?ve ever had.

Aroma was a little weak for me but the coffee makes it way through. Its appearance  is pitch black with a thin brown head. It taste great. With a hint of chocolate that gives way to the distinct more than average coffee flavor. The coffee flavor lingers on my tongue just enough for me to want to have more.

16.9oz bottle for Christmas morning, 2011.  Pours dark, black, thick, and opaque.  A massive mocha-colored 3-finger head slowly recedes and leaves blebby lacing.  Aromas of caramel, toffee, and alcohol; not a ton of coffee, really.  The flavor is roasted malt, bitter cocoa, coffee/espresso, and a mildly tart coffee finish.  Medium carbonation and body, and a bit oily.  Good, but not great.  A little bit of a let-down.   [920]

Bottle at home. Black and hazy with dark brown head that fades fast. Delicious aromas of roasted malt, coffee and dark chocolate. The flavours mirrors the aroma with a medium+ bitterness. A thick and oily mouthfeel. This is a fantastic beer, and excellent with cheese.

Wow this one was phenomenal! Popped the bottle in the fridge for maybe 15 minutes and that was all I could wait. Pours an inky black with a prominent dark brown foam that laces beautifully the whole way down. Not surprisingly this beer has a lot in common with Nogne-Os Imperial Stout, but there is just more going on, and it is much more refined. Aromas are full of dark chocolates, a hint of anise, oak spice, and a wave of espresso. This beer is full bodied and full of flavor. Thick and velvety on the palate. Flavors match the aroma nicely. Chocolates and espresso all the way through. The alcohol makes no presence as the barrel aging has obviously mellowed it out. One of the best beers I have ever tasted. Amazing, get your hands on one!

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2012 Bottle at home, courtesy of an embarrassing F1 bet loss. Worth it, might have to lose on purpose next time. Like Nelson Piquet Jr did. Pours a deep opaque black with a tiny brown film which fades quickly. Aroma is coffee, with chocolate. Powerful and brilliant. Taste has a lot to match up to, and it manages it. Really rich coffee (definitely that classic, rich kopi luwak), with deep chocolatey notes, a little hop spice as well. Definite oatmeal sweetness too. Complex and gorgeous. Perfect mouthfeel, a little alcohol warming but no burn. Excellent. (100th rating!)
En botella color negro oscuro denso con espuma beige.aromas cafeteros,torrefactos y lupulo. Al paladar perfectamente equilibrada,melosa,deliciosa!

Gift from SJ.

Lets start off by saying wow!

Beautiful bold black pour with thick beige head. The appearence alone screams drink me you fool!

Aromas of  burnt roasted malt, dark chocolate and coffee. "How could I resist," I replied.

Flavors of fresh hop, coffee, roasted malt with an abundance of smooth, dark chocolate. "I had my way with this beer. Oh yes I did."

aromas of espresso, tar liquorice molasses. Absolutely wondeful mouthfeel and body typical of an oatmeal stout. extremely complex flavours include vanilla and ash notes  in a coffee stout background. Much too complex for me to describe properly with date, nut, liquorice, plum and a smoke hint.
Awesome beer, well deserved of the top 25 in the world ranking it carries
coffee, earthy, licorice, brown foam, full body, creamy, sticky, long finish, superb beer!
Viscous black pour with brown head. Aromas of roasted malts and coffee. Flavors of roasted malts, coffee and chocolate. Full body with minimal carbonation and a thick, oily mouthfeel.

Pour pitch black, with a solid one-inch head. 
Plenty of roasted malt. Lots of chocolate, finished by a dry bitterness. Lots and lots of coffee. Really Nice. 
The taste is at first quite sweet, but begonies more bitter towards the end, when the mocca flavours takes over. 
Medium and oily body, with a flat carbonation.

Bottle from Vinmonopolet. Pours black with a small light brown head. Aroma of roasted malt with delicious coffee and dark chocolate. Some sweetness balanced by a good bitterness. Very smooth. Long lasting (dry) aromatic finish. Delicious Imperial Stout!

04.11.2011. 0.5l Bottle. vinmonopolet.no. Black colour with dark brown head. Very rich beer with strong aroma of dark roasted malts. Oily mothfeel at first with strong alcohol and rich dry bitterness. Very good flavours of hops with notes of spruce and juniperus together with spices and coffee. The coffee also gives this beer a very dry mouthfeel together with the bitter hops. Rich flavours of dark maÃ¸ts give a very solid body. This is really a very good beer!!
In the top 5 RISs ive had...Coffee flavor is amazing, roast,licorice,cocoa..Deep and complex, I civet you not this might be underrated....yum-me weasel

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2013 Bottle from local Vinmonopol (thanks beer geek employee!). Batch #697, brewed in september -11, so its pretty fresh. Pours as black as they come, with about half an inch of pretty brown head! Head seems to be quickly going down as we speak. In the nose I get a great coffee aroma, chocolate, some sweet red fruityness slightly reminiscent of strawberries. Time to take a sip! Whoa! That was... a lot! Very smooth and full mouthfeel, soft carbonation. Coffee and some kind of licoriceishness (is that a word?) dominate the flavor, the coffee flavors being quite strong, yet still somewhat smooth. Or perhaps its better to say "well-integrated"? Because it fits perfectly. Well-balanced beer overall. Tons of roasted dark malts. Lots of bitterness. Very long lasting finish and aftertaste, with a wonderful nutty coffee flavor in the end. The alcohol is definitely present, but well masked by all the other stuff thats going on here. Some fruity notes are present as well. Hints of caramel in the finish. Really dry finish, I like that. Wow, there so much going on here, Im having trouble describing it all, especially as its changing slightly with every sip. I believe this is the best coffee stout Ive tried so far.Bottle #2, from same batch as previous tasting. Tasted October 21, 2013. My god, the coffee flavor (especially in the neverending aftertaste) is incredible. Like eating the most awesomely roasted coffee beans in the universe. A slightly sweet note of caramel follows the roasted coffee aftertaste. Incredible. Extreme. Amazing.

UPDATED: SEP 22, 2012 
50 cl bottle. Batch #470. Brewed on 01.12.2009. BBE 01.12.2012.
Some stronger vanilla notes have appeared on the aroma and also a bit more intense tar presence. Vanilla is stronger on the flavor also, the liquorice seems to be a bit saltier. Both progressions to my liking. I like the way this is going.
Rating before re-rate: 9+5+8+4+17.
50 cl bottle. Batch #470. Brewed on 01.12.2009. BBE 01.12.2012.
Originally rated on 20100219. (9+5+9+4+17)
Pours pitch black colour with small rapidly dissipating beige head. Aroma of strong coffee, espresso, ash, chocolate, mocha, dark roasted malts, mild tar, wood and some distant caramel and liquorice. Flavour of ash dry chocolate, burnt coffee, roasted malts, some distant whiskey-like alcohol notes, mild caramel and peat. Full-bodied and quite complex, rich flavour with an oily texture. Sweetish and very dry palate with a bitter bite at the end. Definitely a slow-drinking beer. Top notch.
5417
Oily black. Some brown head. Very slick and thick mouthfeel. Could use more carbonation. Malt and alcohol nose. Quite bitter taste. Both malt and hop aroma. Coffee. Red fruit. Good.

During Mikkels and Thomass visit in Athens, Oct 2009. Pitch black with a lovely dense brown head. Lots of heavy roasted malt, chocolate, great coffee character. Sweet malty taste in the beginning, then lots of roasted notes, chocolate,vanilla, great coffee taste leads to dry bitter finish. Amazing mouthfeel, full body. Makes you want more and more. One of the best I ever had.

Rich and viscous black pour and temporary teak head. Subtle smoky coffee. Coffee fills the mouth and coats every surface with underlying chocolate and a ling roasty and astringent finish. Alcohol tingle but otherwise very well balanced.

Tasted November 17. 2011: Delicious beer with taste of coffee. Balanced brew.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Strong Coffee flavor which overpowers a bit. Good but the balance is lacking slightly

500ml bottle from IPB.
Appearance : Pitch black with medium sized thick brown creamy head. 

Aroma : Deep roasted malt with coffee. Rich dark chocolate. Really rich and smooth. Quite a lot of hops.

Taste : Great roasted malt with some hops. Big coffee notes with dark chocolate. Finish is awesome with dark chocolate and coffee. Some alcohol but not a lot considering the abv. 

Palate : Very smooth carbonation. Palate is soft and silky. Great mouthfeel.

Overall : Very rich and tasty. Nice balance between coffee, chocolate and hops. Coffee is there but it doesnt overpowers the rest. Quite drinkable with great mouthfeel.

EPIC! Pours motor oil black with a short lived mocha head. The aroma is black licorice anise through that wazoo, roasty coffee, and cocoa. The flavour is again, huge licorice, tons of the stuff, coffee, some nuttiness, ends on a salty/sweet note. Slightly dry mouthfeel. Flippin awesome.

Bottle at home, cant believe I havent rated it before! Deep thick inky black pour, tiniest cocoa brown head fades to absolutely nothing. Looks like crude oil in a glass!! Nose is restrained, hints of cocoa and coffee and roasty goodness. Palate is reasonably dry, with a slightly bittersweet dark chocolate touch. Oatmeal is definitely present too, rounded and nutty. Real coffee too, but not in an aggressive way. Hint of salty smokiness too, big coffee bitter finish. Some booze, but very mild. Phenomenal!

Date: November 5, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: BVery
Opaque black with light brown head, full bodied, smooth with soft carbonation, aroma and taste of espresso.  Another great impy stout from Mikkeller.

50cl bottle, 2009 vintage, tulip glass.
Pours a viscous black, with a small brown head.
Smells of rich dark chocolate, with a hint of coffee.
Tastes bitter like a black espresso; once overcome, the chocolate returns and some sweetness is evident. Lingers with a bitter aftertaste.
Its a lot like drinking a thick creamy black espresso.
Overall, more bitter than Id have expected, but still very tasty. I think my preference goes to the BGBreakfast.

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2013 Bottle. Jet black pour with an awesome frothy brown head. Aroma of roasted coffee and bacon. Slick coating palate. Taste is very rich - espresso, milk chocolate.....this is absolutely killer.

Dark brown head - actually i have never seen anything like this. Only it falls after a short time. The beer itself is pitch black. the nose has bacon, barbecue crisps as well as some sweetnes, chockolate, coffee. amazing! It is absolutely massive in the mouth but also very easy sliding down the throat. Faaantastic! Its is chocolate, coffee and a hoppy cleaning out in the end. Very fine and actually extremely wellballanced. Way above the std. beer geek!

At first glance, a little intimidating. It pours thick, black and viscous with the smallest sheet of orange-brown bubbles. It smells like espresso, chocolate, alcohol, smoke all very pungent and intense. The flavor is the same; intense rich chocolate and java black as night. Its smooth and slick, soft carbonation with a bitter, yet sweet, somewhat medicinal finish. To say its full flavored is an understatement. Its a meal in a bottle.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2014 50 cl bottle @ home, #418: brewed 23.03.2009, BBE 23.03.2012
Nøgne version
Pitch black with large, big-bubbled head. Aroma has coffee and licorice. Flavour is slightly acidic with coffee and slightly salty licorice. Alcohol warms a bit but does not taste. Somewhat foamy palate. One of the best beers Ive had.

9+5+9+4+19=4.6

33 cl bottle @ home, BBE 09.05.2014
Re-rate with Lervig version
Head is fizzy and disappears very quickly. Aroma is rather nice with vanilla and lots of coffee. Also a slight feeling of jalopeno-like vegetables typical to coffee beers. Flavour has coffee, some licorice and mocha. A bit too fizzy carbonation. Still quite awesome.

9+4+9+4+19=4.5

UPDATED: APR 22, 2012 Beer # 1000! In bottle at home with Sev. Pours a beautiful black colour with a fair dark tan head. Aroma of coffee, dark chocolate and caramel. Alcohol is perfectly balanced on the nose and in the flavour. Big upfront coffee flavour also with roasty malt, caramel and dark chocolate again. Lovely thick, oily mouth-feel and a roasty, bitter dark chocolate linger. Mild carbonation and CO2 prickle. Superb! Also had this on keg at the BrewDog Bar, Glasgow. Poured a jet black colour with a decent, dark tan head. Smelled sweeter than I remember with alcohol, caramel, espresso coffee, roasty malt and chocolate notes. Delicious with similar flavours and a lovely long roasty malt linger and alcohol hum (9,4,9,4, 18). Such a great beer!

Bottle (2009).
Pitch black with a thick brown head that didnt lace. 
Big intense aroma of coffee beans, dark chocolate, lots of roasted malts and meaty woody soy with a hint of tar pastille.
Taste is sweet, rich and thick with lots of luxurious coffee and dark chocolate, burnt malts meaty soy and tar and licorice.
Full bodied, thick and sticky with soft carbonation.
This is just how I want my imperial stout.

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2013 2009 Vintage [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Moeder Lambic: wow, this is amazing, pitch-black with a thick, creamy mocha head, taste is sweet upfront, amazing, sweet coffee/berry-like taste upfront that I cannot exactly describe but otherwise creamy, mocha ice-cream, liquorice, berries, toasted wood, cream, sweet coffee, sweet chocolate, thick, creamy malts, smooth oatmeal, slightest hint of roast, slight cinnamon, smooth, perfectly balanced, slight bitter coffee, chocolate aftertaste //// Tried the new version, draft @ Borefts 2013. Different but just as good as the old one, the coffee is more forward in this one, sweet coffee with a lovely red berry quality to it upfront. Still easily one of the best RIS in existence in my opinion.

8-10-11 bouteille: Noire opaque, avec une moussse beige et épaisse et peu deffervescence. Crémeuse. Délicieux arômes asser difficile à décrire, mais avec une note de café pas trop amer et des touches de chocolats. Très bien balancée avec une légèreté sucrée, une moyenne amertume qui nest pas tranchante.  Corps moyen, velouté, raffraichissante, fruitée pour une bière a base de café. Possiblement la meilleure biere au café que jai eu loccasion de boire. Se différencie vraiment. Un délice!

Along with Dogfish Heads World Wide Stout, this beer is one of my two favorite beers of all time. Perfection in a glass. Almost overwhelming chocolate and coffee up front, both aroma and taste, and then straight up velvety smooth stout enjoyment thereafter. Big body, low carbonation, flavor to die for, and lingering finish. It doesnt get better in my book.

Pours black with dark brown head, low retention.  Aroma is smoky, intensely earthy coffee, green hops, and a massively roasty chocolate body.  Taste is same as the smell, very well balanced but super earthy all around.  Body is medium heavy, creamy, below average carbonation, hoppy roasty coffee finish.  Overall, a rare and delicious treat from Mikkeller.  Poop in a glass never tasted so good!

Pours a deep black color with a nice, lacing head. Distinct coffee aroma. Some roasted malt notes as well. Very smooth. Reminds me of an iced coffee with the flavor. Very impressive, yet silky smooth. Some dark chocolate in there as well. Complicated, and very impressive.
(Brasserie 4:20) Simply perfect..cloudy black,chocolate coffee,vanilla taste...bitter dry finish,good balance

Ported from BA.

Stout for lunch on a 60 degree day? Okay!

Appearance:
Pours an oily, slick black with 2 fingers of brown head. Held up to a sunny window, no light makes it all the way through the beer. This stuff is BLACK.

Smell: 
Sweetness, like chocolate, booze, and subtle coffee. No strong guess as to which flavor will dominate the taste.

Taste:
Sweetness and oats hit me first, and then I get a blast of booze and chocolate. The chocolate is actually fairly dry feeling. Another flavor is in there too, which starts small and gradually takes over your entire mouth. What is it exactly? At first I didnt know, and then it hit me: This is ultra-rich coffee! Wow!

Mouthfeel:
Oily and thick, and mouth-coating. You could chew on this stuff like gum.

Overall:
Im pretty sure I would drink this with breakfast. It would be delicious. The only thing stopping me is the 10.9% ABV. Im a little concerned about having it for lunch, in fact. glad Im not driving today. Other than that, this stout is fantastic. A coffee-lovers stout, and a stout-lovers breakfast.

Bottle, split with mcberko. Pours solid black with a thick tan foamy head. Aroma of bacon, toasted wood, campfire, bourbon, toasted nuts and dark treacle. Flavour of bacon, lots of smoked wood, dark strong coffee, roasted caramel malts, oatmeal, chocolate and hops - very rich. Booze is well-hidden. Intense, complex and really nice.
Smell of licorice and mead. Black, oily with dark brown head. Aroma of coffee, nuts and chocolate. Pretty awesome.

500mL bottle, pours a beautiful black with a small tan head. Aroma of rich roasted malt, prominent coffee, oatmeal and a noticeable hop presence. Flavour is intensely rich, with loads of rich roasted malt, potent coffee, considerable hoppiness, some chocolate and oats. Extremely rich (about as rich as beer can be), full-bodied, complex, thick, velvety and silky smooth. Quite harsh, really, but fantastic for what it is.
From tap. Poured a thick black with hardly a tan head. Smelled of roasted coffee and malts. Tasted bitter, with malts coming to the fore. Thick body with the perfect level of carbonation. Excellent.
Notes of coffee, cocoa, and alcohol. On the palate the beer is thinner then I might have expected. Still a richness of cocoa, coffee, and caramel. Good brew.

Bottle thanks to Bigmmartin, pours pitch black with a nice dark tan head and some lacing, the aroma has a huge coffee front with notes of chocolate and a hint of booze, the flavor has a ton of chocolate and coffee with a long lasting chocolate finish that coats your entire mouth, wow, this is awesome.

Pours pitch black with a nice brown head.  Smells coffee, chocolate, alcohol and a hint of cold hot dogs.  Super smooth, creamy body coats the tongue with deep, dark chocolate, fresh coffee beans, and a hint of citrus that for some reason combines to taste like cold hot dogs to me.  A fantastic oatmeal stout, perfection of body and supple in flavor.  Give me some goat cheese!

Bottle; Pour is murky dark brown with a fine bubbled, dark khaki head that retains fairly well; while eventually hazing this glass - very light, spotty lacing.  The nose is cocoa, coffee beans, and oatmeal, naturally. The flavor profile provides a bitterness from the hop profile, as well as from the coffee notes. The coffee story here is interesting. Chocolate, a hint of smoke, caramel, toffee - a nice imperial.

A very solid oatmeal stout, probably on of my favorite for the style. For the most part I find Mikkeller to be a to taste love it or hate it brewer with lots of gimmickry. This beer however seems to transcend the gimmickry.

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2011 Black with a rich warm-brown head that is 8mm thick but fades to naught within a minute.  Aroma is earthy sap and coffee- tons of it.  A bit of sweetness, warm caramel.  Thick palate with prickly carbonation.  Moderate sweetness up front (caramal notes are masked by other stuff).  Packed with flavor! but not BBQ or Soy sauces.  Earthy, piney, sappy hops covering a big coffee flavor.  Theres so much going on here that it covers any of the stale coffee flavors that might otherwise be present (as there are in other coffee stouts.)  Burnt toast, nuts, and oats.  The Bitterness lingers on and on in a refreshing and lovely way.  Not overly harsh though.  Overall, very good, but perhaps a bit too much flavor going on, at least for the summer.
Sampled at Alvinne CBF 2011. Black color, decent smell and nice taste. Good mouthfeel. Very nice imperial stout.

Poured from a bottle into a snifter. Roasted coffee on the nose, very dark brown in appearance. Coffee forward, but nothing too impressive. Maybe the bottle I had was not fresh? Solid coffee stout, but not worth drinking poop, at least based on my tasting of it.

Pours BLACK with a super thick brown head that doesnt last. Subtle roasted aroma, with a bit of tang. Flavor is less coffee than expected, but I guess that because the coffee has already been digested. Great bitter sweet, somewhat boozy stout.

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2012 This stout is so dark and thick that from its pour you might be led to think its crude oil (or at least a kind of it that happens to develop a minimal tan head as it is poured). Speaking of head, it is so minimal that I only speak of it because convention tells me to. The aroma is damn impressive, with sweet, delicate Kopi Luwak coffee; roasted malts (which do come through nicely, despite the coffee addition), elegant hops, and alcohol. Overall, the nose is not exactly boozy, but the alcohol is not as elegantly tuned into it as it is in, say, Stone IRS. The taste is mostly bitter, with some sweetness coming from the Kopi Luwak, but I thought I was going to get more of a coffee character here. The coffee is very mellow and, really, second to the roasted malts. The palate is very thick and elegantly carbonated. It may well be too thick for some, but I think it suits the style perfectly. This is some heavyweight stuff. Its not as Civet Coffeeoriented as I thought it would be, but God, it is lovely. I just wish the alcohol didnt become so obvious past a certain temperature. A big thanks to The Charleston Beer Exchange for this one.

Holy beep. Civetshitcoffee. I prefer my coffee with milk because it is too bitter. Same for this one. Let me be honest, this beer is quite amazing. I started this a little too cold and every sip was different. Rich with coffee, chocolate, earth, peat, red fruit. Almost syruppy in viscosity.

Poured in tulip from bottle. Pours a dark chocolate almost black with a very thin cream head. The aroma is burnt espresso with hints of mocha which comes through in the taste.  Like a warm chocolate milk, shockingly thin mouth feel for as dark it is.  But overall a very good beer, not sure if it is better then non-weasel version. (also all the poop jokes made while drinking)

Kolsvart med medelstort brunt skum. Fantastiska dofter. Luktar lätt vinöst, kaffe, choklad, soya och portvin. Smakar som det doftar och uppfyller förväntningarna. Alkoholen binder ihop, skapar värme och styrka. Mycket fylligt men med en överaskande liten beska vilket jag tycker är bra.

Smoky, spicy, paprika, coffee is smooth and the smoke is strong. Flavor is strong, but smooth, like an espresso. I love how the oatmeal adds a smooth silliness, while the coffee really fills your mouth.

Extreme black with virtually no head. Aroma is coffee, burnt sugar, molasses and dark fruit. Mouthfeel is oily. Taste starts sweet and fruity - blueberries, dark fruits and caramel - then moves on to a chewy nuttiness before finishing with a coffee bitterness. Quite a complex beer that manages to tie together some unique flavours.

50 cl, bottled. Pours black with a light brown head. Aroma: Sal ammoniac, licorice, coffee, malt, dark chocolate. Taste: Sweetish, High coffee-like bitterness. Intensive coffee and salty licorice. Hints of leather. Great. Palate: Full bodied, creamy, soft, slightly salty aftertaste with hops and coffee. Amusing dryness. Soft carbonation. Very nice brew, well done.

This beer looked blacker than black. It smelt like roasted coffee with oats and dark chocolate. Taste was rich and creamy, the chocolate and coffee coming through strongly. Other flavours I couldnt tell what they were. The finish went on forever and was beautifully smooth. Large amounts of sediment at the bottom of the bottle. Fantastic beer

50 cl bottle from Kihoskh, Copenhagen. Pitch black liquid with beautiful, thick brown head. Aroma is roasted with notes of dark chocolate, really nice coffee, dark fruits, leather and oats. Some light herbal and earthy hops. Taste has lots of delicious coffee and licorice notes. Medium bitter and light to medium sweet. Very well balanced. Smooth mouthfeel with full body and ok carbonation. Absolutely delicious beer, for a coffee lover like me this is wonderful. Such balance and no boozyness at all, at 10.9%! Great beer.

Bottle.
Pitch black with a creamy brown head.
Aroma: coffee, oatmeal cookies, chocolate, raisins.
Taste: chocolate, coffeee, licorice, salt, granola or some other kind of crunchy müsli , oatmeal cookies with raisins.
Full-bodied and really smooth.
coffee, roasty, grass, earthy, full body, thick feel, long finish, black, medium bitterness,

Schenkt als een dikke bruine zwarte koffie. De schuimkraag is dik romig en ruikt naar eiken houten vaten. De smaak van dit bier is dik en romig, chocolade, koffie en zelfs in de verte een beetje wijnachtig. Prachtig complex bier voor op een rustig moment. De nasmaak is langdurig bitter en houtachtig. Het alcoholpercentage is prachtig gecamoufleerd.

Poors like a thick brownish / black coffee. The foam is thick and creamy and smells like oak wood barrels. The taste of this beer is thick and creamy, choclate, coffee and in the back even a little wine. Beautiful complex beer to enjoy on a quiet moment. The after taste is bitter and woody.The alcohol percentage is beautifully camouflaged.

Bottled. Pitch black, oily beer with thin but lasting beige head. Insanely rich aroma has sweet oats, dark dried fruits, loads of roastedness and aromatic, slightly nutty coffee. A hint of vanilla? Not particularly hoppy aroma, but there are some herbal notes in it. Starts sweet and clearly oaty. Dryer finish is bitterish and it has light sourness of roasted malts and coffee. Full bodied, silky soft and oily palate.
Pours dark black with coffee and licorice notes.  Mouthfeel shows even deeper notes of earth, coffee, light cocoa, caramel, and licorice.  a long balanced finish.

Bottle 0,5l, pours pitch black with large fluffy creamy light brown head... nose... lots coffee/caramel ! nice! for the tongue and mouthfeel very nice caramel, coffee, licorice,cream,sweet... creamy body.... bitter sweet with caramel finish.... :)

Pours black.  Kinda a small head.  Nose is deep dark roasted malts, strong coffee, Kinda a sour like roast in the nose.  Flavor is extremely bitter roasted coffee, dark malts and bread like malts.  Thick and viscous on the palate.  Really a little too bitter and acrid to be  very enjoyable.
Dark dark brown with a small creamy head. Coffe and chocolate all the way in a very full body. I would switch this for my morningcoffe anytime!

Bottle @ DØE meeting. Pours black with a light brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, dark choclate. Taste is rich roasted malt, cold coffee, expresso, dark chocolate, licorice. Full, very creamy body, soft carbonation. Lovely. 190210

Bottle enjoyed at home in a proper nosing glass
This gem pours pitch black as used engine oil with a wonderful 2 cm dark brown head that sinks down to a thin head after some time. The look is just amazing. Aroma of coffee, chocolate and more coffee! The aroma is so elegant, minimalistic and excuisite. Taste is full malt bodied with some good sweetness. Taste has also coffee, chocolate and liquorice. Feel is very oily. Finish has nice hop and malt bitterness. Also bitterness from the coffee i guess? This is a top quality beer that in different to some other beers on the top shelf dont have any need of barrel aging.

Fresh out of a very cold cooler. The smell is an INTENSE bitter dark chocolate. 

The taste is the same. Some roasted malt character to it, but the main flavor is like the darkest cacao chocoalte bar you have ever had. Very tasty... but as it warms a very smoky flavor starts to develop. Not the most fond of this flavor. but I had made my way through most of the glass!

a very good beer IMO, will have to remember to serve this pretty cold and drink it on the faster side with some ice cream or something!
Dark brown with a small brown head. Fruty and malty tones. Malt, coffe and chocolate. Full body with a long bittersweet finish.
Pitch dark black body with a dark brown head. Amazing aroma of great coffee and dark chocolate. Full bodied, rich coffee flavour with alcohol and a bitter finish. A really great beer.
Smells of coffee. Pours black with tan head. Flavour is rich, full bodied stout with strong coffee notes. Tastes of good quality coffee. Stunning drink

Draught at Mikkeller Bar.
Black with a light brown head. Aroma heavy malty (roasted, light burnt, vanilla, chocolate, coffee). Flavor moderate+ sweet, not to much, perfect balanced. Full-bodied, smooth, with the alcohol well hidden.
Poured thick black with a small dark head. Smells like coffee and oysters. Tastes heavy with a bit of bitterness/tang. Stellar beer.

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2011 The perfect coffee imperial stout. The coffee is not too prominent (which is a good thing). I dont like those beers that taste like carbonated coffee with a shot. Everything is well integrated, sweet roast, coffee beans, bakers chocolate. Awesome beer. Best stout Ive ever had.

Bottle from CP&K. It pours jet black, with a thick dark tan head and moderate carbonation. The nose is rich-roast coffee, varnish, soy sauce, salt, dark chocolate, milk chocolate, toffee and caramel. The taste is rich-roast coffee, liquorice, bitter chocolate, wood, toasted sesame seed, charcoal, tar, salt, caramel, toffee, date and raisin, with a very long rich, roasty finish. Full bodied, complex, well balanced and indulgent. Great, but I think the BG Breakfast is a bit more drinkable.
Draught at Copenhagen Beer Festival 2011. Black with a brown head. Aroma and flavour of coffee, chocolate, spice, roasted malt, alcohol and caramel.

Draft taster at Bavarian Lodge. A solid black body and dark brown head. The smell is light coffee, with a slight tang of orange peel. The first sip kind of vibrates on my tongue. The coffee aspect is mild, yet spicy. Like a light roast Sumatra coffee, and none of the roast malt of the usual strong stout. Light on alcohol. Some vanilla notes midway through my glass. After taking my notes, I looked up more details on this coffee, and found that "weasel coffee" is supposedly made much more mellow, even fermented, by enzymes during its trip through the critters GI. Not having tried the actual coffee, I can only say its reported characteristics come out very nicely in this beer. Ive also learned that Vietnamese researchers have isolated the enzymes that make the coffee and may be mass producing it, as the ca phe chon civet is possibly endangered.

Deep black with head erupting from the surface slowly and evenly.  Sweet, dark fruits, vanilla in the nose.  Slightest of roast malt/coffee.  Flavor is fairly sweet - chocolate milk, molasses, vanilla, roasted malt, mild burnt biscuit, and somewhere...mostly in the background...the coffee flavor.  Wish this would have been profiled a little better considering the concept.  Plump on the palate and a masterpiece of consistency.  Smooth and velvety.  A very good imp, but guess I was expecting just a little more.

Purchased at Discount Liquors in Milwaukee, WI; enjoyed with a good friend to celebrate a new job!  Appearance pitch black with oil like consistency and rich tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, strong coffee presence, lactose, its in a plastic cup so unfortunately that may alter the aroma a bit, but it smells delicious.  Taste is...oh wow.  Very rich in a strong, dark coffee thats almost espresso like with huge chocolate, mint, and mocha notes.  Extremely decadent and delicious.  Will hopefully enjoy again!

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2012 (6.6.11) 500mL bottle @ TapRoom.  Pours completely opaque with small tan head.  So obviously this is expected to be chocolate and coffee, which it is.  Nose also has a bit of a hop.  On the tongue this is simply delicious.  I dont often drink coffee, but when I do, I prefer Vietnamese coffee...and this Vietnamese coffee has created the most delicious coffee taste I have ever gotten from a beer.  Above-average texture (though not exceptionally thick).  Purchasing this at a bar meant it was fairly expensive, yet still it was almost worth the price by itself.  My recollection of the Beer Geek Breakfast from long ago was that it was amazing, but this is my first Mikkeller since then...I will definitely be doing everything I can, now, to find more.
