Poured Black with a large brown head and persistent brown ring. Nice coffee aroma that dominates most of the aroma.  Sweet nose with some cocoa.  Roasty malt with a moderate sweetness and mild coffee.  Smooth mouthfeel.  Medium to full bodied.  Warming in the chest.

Thanks to OSCF for sharing this one!  Dark brown pour with nice retention and spotty lace.  Nice coffee character on the nose.  Creamy mouth feel with lots of chocolate and thick heavy roast.  I picked up some light coffee on the finish, but not as much as I expected.

UPDATED: JUN 12, 2012 Aroma of smoke, wood, roasted malt, café au lait. Amazingly rich and creamy in the mouthperfect body. Huge complexity with a charcoal and coffee finish. One of the best of its kind. Wow!

Thanks for sharing Yaniv!  Dark dark brown with almost no head.  Dark malt, alcohol.  Lighter coffee, sweet with some roast, perhas some brown sugar.  Medium to full consistency with low carbonation.  Sweet.  Alcohol, some chocolate and dark malt character.  Coffee, smooth and light.  Fruity slightly astringent finish.  A significant improvement over the standard Beer Geek, but I think most of that must come from the mash rather than the beans.

I figured drinking this for my 200th is a solid choice.  Pours black into snifter with a large beige head.  Aroma is weasel poo consisting of a carnivorous mixture of mice, rabbits, gophers,  chipmunks and the ocassional coffee bean (had to do it).  No this brew has a STRONG coffee, smokey, and chocolate aroma.  Might be one of the strongest coffee aromas out there in a beer, (maybe peche mortal compares?) Flavor is great, at first I thought it might be too strong for the flavor profile but there is a nice hop and malt backbone to make it quite enjoyable.  Not as much coffee in the flavor as you would think by the aroma.  The hops surprised me the most such a solid addition to the typical smoky malt and chocolate malt profile.  Finish is slightly dry and slightly bitter.  A thoughly enjoyable beer.  
Oh yeah in case you wondered if more is coming I found this at the Mikkeller website:

"It is not unproblematic to get your hands on sufficient amounts of the rare and very expensive weasel pooh coffee. But now it seems that a delivery is underway. A Vietnamese coffee plantation owner has promised to deliver the coffee immediately. He reports that on his plantation no weasels go to bed hungry . Every morning he gets out of bed when the dawn is still cracking only to collect the precious pooh. Very soon all the pooh will be send to Nøgen Ø (Naked Island) in Norway where Mikkel will brew the next batch of Beer Geek Brunch in the middle of April"

Fresh batch in April!

Rating 300 - thanks to VikingHammer for the bottle! Now *this* is a coffee stout! Pours black, with a thick, dark tan head. Fresh, dark roasted coffee and cacao on the nose, a bit of molasses and dark brown sugar. This stuff is smooth as butter, enough carbonation to keep the palate lively. Deep, roasty coffee flavor - I can really tell this would be very, very good coffee - but it doesnt overwhelm the rest of whats in here... dark chocolate, very dark brown sugar, and oak. It has a wonderful balance - Im not used to liking a coffee stout this well, but it seems so well integrated. I could see this pairing beautifully with a creme brulee.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2009 great things in life:  puppies. sex. live music.  beer geek brunch weasel.

believe the hype.

pours deep black with a heavy tan head that take a while before diminishing off.
nose is chocolate.  sweet molasses, roasted hops and surprisingly only a hint of coffee notes.  a tinge of alcohol is also noticeable.
mouthfeel is silky sweet and pretty heavy.  now for the flavor... smokey chocolate and a woody bitterness that leads into the hit of coffee.  high alcohol is only slightly noticeable.  Lots of great flavors and a rather complex beer.  in my top 3 favorites, now im hoping they make it in a 6 pack for only $6.99.

Ummm... there is something about scatological  brews that is disturbing. I remember my dad used to say: "So, if all of your friends ate shit, would you join them?", in response to an: "Everyone else was doing it..." statement.
I think the guests on Maury have more sense!
Here is a thought... just soak the coffee in a similar enzyme that eliminates the shit-picking stage.
Mmmmm! That stuff leaves a shit-eating grin on my face!

500ml bottle.  Pours black with a nice mocha colored head, great retention and lacing.   Aromas of bittersweet chocolate, oats, roasted malts, some dark fruit, a hint of smoke and of course coffee, lots of coffee.  Flavors are are sweet roasted malts and chocolate up front.  Coffee and bittersweet chocolate linger on the palate for a while.  Palate is rich, and full bodied.  Great beer, I would drink more, not sure if I would pay $16 again though.

500 mL bottle. Very excited to try this beer, as I loved Mikkellers Beer Geek Breakfast, and had heard this was even better. Pours a magnificent opaque black color with a small dark tan head that disappates quickly. Smells of fresh oatmeal, some roasted bittersweet chocolate, and a smooth rich coffee smell. Immediately strong taste of great rich coffee, with the oatmeal and chocolate coming later, and mixing very smoothly with the coffee flavor. Goes down fairly smoothly, is full-bodied, and leaves a mocha-like aftertaste (the chocolate and coffee flavor mixed). Overall a great beer, that I was not disappointed by, and would love to try again; definitely worth the money.

Bottle : The aroma consists of espresso, chocolate, faint fruit, and smoke.  It pours a dark brown, virtually black, with a small brown head with okay retention.  The flavor starts with chocolate.  The finish has light-moderate roasted coffee and fruit.  Full bodied with a soft mouthfeel.

A 0.5L bottle tasted at Pikkulintu. Chocolate in the nose. Brown fast dissappearing head. Dark brownish colour. Slightly sour coffeish tatse. Softness and bitterness well balanced. Soft like silk. Some hoppiness in the nose. Warming alcohol.

Quite a nice imperial stout.  Dark black pour with a large creaym tan head.  This stout is quite soft, with creamy milk chocolate, roasted coffee beans, light smokey malt, very light on the fruit.  Mostly chocolate and roasty coffee.  Fairly complex and nice, silky mouth feel. mmm poop coffee.

Bottle shared with Katie and wetherel during a small afternoon tasting at our place in Del Mar. Pours and oily pitch black with a soft-textured tan head that sticks well to the snifter. Aroma is a pleasing aroma of dark chocolates and coffee bean. The coffee character in the nose is not overdone however, but pretty well balanced with the dry and smoky roasted malt. Nose became a bit metallic after sitting for a couple of minutes, losing some points. Nice flavors of cocoa powder and more coffee follow up, with a dry chocolate and smoke character throughout. Palate is what kept my points up here; very smooth and silky on the back of the tongue. For some reason the palate reminds me of that of Amager Hr. Frederiksen. Roasty, medium-length finish. Definitely a good beer, but I consider it marginally a Top 50.
Oh yeah!   Super complex, layered and awesome.   I should say more, but Im speechless.

Bottle.  Completely opaque brown-black with just a little light brown around the edges.  Tight tan head.  Big dark chocolate and coffee aroma - cherry, cranberry, lightly earthy.  Really well balanced aroma, hops well balanced by smokiness, slightly vinous.  Big flavor, more dark chocolate and coffee.  Long bitter finish and less fruit complexity than the aroma.  Warming alcohol.  The coffee is probably the most well integrated part of the flavor, but the flavor is way heavy on the toasty/roasty notes, which throws it out of balance for me.  Excellent beer though.

My Million Beer March Tasting. Sample from a bottle thanks to decaturstevo.  Pitch black with a tan head.  Aroma of coffee, big roast.  Taste is more big roast body, big burnt roast coffee, chocolate.  Excellent though I wonder how much the Kopi Luwak actually adds.

bottle. 
im all about the weasel poop. i have to ask, if the poop tastes this good, what does the weasel taste like? i must find out. pours black with a brown orange head. smells of roasted orange peels an assload of coffee(pun intended) a liquid version of a chocolate covered coffee bean. good coffee flavor with a perfect chocolate balance. im treating this like a good marbled ribeye, i cant stop. nice and thick and treats me right. acidic finish that is all coffee.  there is a horrible comment in my notes that i will leave out here, i am a sick sick man.

5 9 9 4 18

Bottle from Justin.  Thanks!  Ive been eager to try this.  Nice coffee taste and aroma.  Very much like regular beer geek brunch, possibly a bit smoother, possibly because it is fresh.  Leans dry, but not too dry.  A little bit roasty.  A little bit of smoke.  Im going to have to go against the 4.6 rating trend for this beer, because Im not a big fan of roastiness, but it has been done pretty well in this week.

Bottle at Eulogy split with Joe, $19. Not a bad price for a bar, considering at stores it is 15. Mild black pour, a little bit of a head. Big, rich coffee aroma, chalky sweet with caramel and melted butter on toast. Alcohol, sweet black malts are evident up front, with chalk and sweet toast in the finish. A bit of fleeting bitterness. Not mind-blowing, very big and tough to drink. 5 years ago this beer would have been ground breaking and incredible, but now its just more of the same.

Bottle poured a translucent dark brown with a small lingering brown head. Aromas of coffee, roasted malt, bitter chocolate and light charcoal. Palate was medium bodied and smooth with a lightly dry finish. Flavors of acidic coffee, bitter chocolate, roasted malt, dark fruit and light carmel with a smooth lightly dry lingering coffee finish.

Kermaisen suklaisen värinen vaahto ja pikimusta väri, suklainen, kahvinen ja paahtuneen maltainen tuoksu, pehmeä ja sopivan makea maku, joka loppuu miellyttävän katkerana. Laatutavaraa, kahvi on tässä elementtinä todella miellyttävästi integroitu, ei päällekäyvä ja antaa muille oluen elementeille mahdollisuuden. Hieno olut, päihitti vertailussa Foundersin breakfast stoutin pienellä marginaalilla ja Terrapinin wake n baken suvereenisti.
In english: Thats damn good coffee.

Bottle shared by bgburdman.   Pours inky black with a smallish brown colored head that pretty much settles out.   Aroma is light coffee, burnt sugar, chocolate.   Flavor is roast, coffee, molasses, burnt sugar.   Palate is massive, mild carbonation, finished sweet.   Did not suck!   Great balance of coffee and stout, superior mouth feel!

2009 Bottle - Thanks pantanap! - Pours a thick, viscous almost black with a small tan head...aroma is sweet coffee, cocoa malt and charred wood...flavour is similarly sweet and creamy with just a hint of alcohol...while a terrific brew, I slightly underwhelmed given the hype and the price, tasty though...

Bottle, poured a dark rich brown body with a tall, airy tan head that left gorgeous lacing on the glass.  Aromas of medium roast coffee, sweet malts and a faint trace of dark chocolate.  The flavor was so balanced and smooth with perfectly melding notes of rich strong coffee, vanilla, steaming oatmeal, and a touch of brown sugar.  The pallate had a velvety feel the remained wet and cool even after the beer warmed.  Hardly a trace of alcohol and a nice sweet malty finish that makes you wish the bottle was never ending.

Bottle. Black coloured with a nice dense cappucino head. Aromas of sweet malt, roasted malt, coffee with sugar and cream, chocolate and carmel. The texture is very smooth. The flavour is sweet and roasted with notes of chocolate and coffee.. The alcohol is very well hidden behind the massive amount of sweetness in this Imperial stout. I think this beer would do well if it was served with a heavy chocolate dessert.

Good, even considering the hype.  Black.  Medium palate, and very smooth.  Tons of roasted malt, a little sugar, and moderate coffee.  I know the rare coffee is a big deal, but when it is in the beer, there is no perceivable quality from the coffee to make it special.  A very good, well made imperial stout.
Bottle. Black colour with a tan head. Aroma is coffee, alcohol, roasted. Flavour is roasted, malt, coffee, alcohol, hop. Extreme coffee beer. I like it.  World class beer.

UPDATED: APR 24, 2010 Bottle shared by ygtbsm94: Pours an oily opaque with dark mahogany edges and a spotty-lacing froth of dark tan head.  Aroma of rich mocha dark caramel and chocolate with lots of fresh coffee and some dark fruity esters.  Body starts with great fullness and rich roasty coffee flavor with some dense dark chocolate with a creamy bittersweet finish.  Well balanced with good complexity and great coffee character with a touch of warmth in the finish.  One of the best coffee stouts Ive had.

On tap at Ørsted Ølbar 8/29/09: Pours an oily opaque black with a small spotty lacing froth of dark tan head.  Aroma of rich sweet dark caramel, chocolate, and coffee along with a touch of dark fruits.  Starts with good thick dark maltiness and sweet caramel with great roasty coffee balance with a molten bittersweet dark chocolate finish.  Very well balanced and complex along with hiding its alcohol well.

Bottle from SL. The pour was just beautiful, tons of well-developed and developing head, strong brown-choco color, nothing pale or tan about it, many fingers thick, solid lacing all the way down, dark brown body with some mahoganey hues, and the best part: little weasel droppings plopping out of the sludge at the bottom, ooooooh, laaaaaa, laaaah! The aroma was strong coffee and some roast, faint chocolate, but not overall that strong. The flavor followed by the coffee was super firm, the roasty bitterness was assertive, and the alcohol was amazingly non-existent in the flavor profile, very impressively done in that regard. Only slight notes of vinous character detected, and again, this thing was roasty, coffee bitter, with a bite (slight acidity?) in the full mouthfeel. Good stuff, although I like the Breakfast sitting a bit better than Brunch.

Courtesy MrBunn. Abyssmal black pour with a head that starts reddish, but ends tan. What it lacks in aroma it makes up for in taste. Exceptional dark roast coffee flavor mixed with rich chocolate.Very smooth and incredibly drinkable.

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2009 Bottle.  Pours a midnight brown with a massive head.  Aromas are fairly weak... a bit of dark malt, oatmeal, and coffee, but I was expecting a little more aggression.  Flavor is a great mix of oatmeal, milk chocolate and coffee malts with a warmth from the ABV, but not much alcohol flavor.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: I have to say this is a fine brew.  Pours black with a tan head.  Aroma of coffee and sweet chocolate.  10.9% abv is well hidden and it is incredibly drinkable.  Great coffee flavor with a lot of sweet chocolate as well.  Glad I bought another bottle :)

Bottle shared by Britt after MTB ride.  Never tasted weasel poop before, but it tastes a lot like coffee, cream, vanilla, and chocolate I guess.  The bottle actually had chunks in it.  Scary.  Excellent brew.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2010 Bottle. Tasted at Ulkløbben.
Black with dark brown head.
Coffee (surprise!) in the nose, and on tasting, but it is not overdone. Very well integrated.
Extraordinary creamy, with a looong aftertaste. Definately more power than the "breakfast".
Best Stout I have ever tasted. It is warm when I drink it, and it is fantastic. Oh, and the ABV does not really show
I could drink this all night
+++
Tasted again 19-MAR-2010 and this time rated 4.6. I really love this beer
+++
Tasted again 28-MAY-2010, @Mikkeller.
Draft, and even better than the bottle version. This time there is a minty note that I have not detected before.
Really world class beer:)

Bottle. Aroma of sweet chocolate, soft, almost milky coffee, and later the more roasted coffee bean notes, and later still reveals some pleasant alcohol. Flavor continues with very smooth chocolate and coffee, delicate in a way. There are notes of wafer malt, but very much chocolate and coffee coated wafer. Quite the treat, probably great as a dessert beer.

Bottle much thanks to tytoanderso, shared with NachlamSie. Pours black with amber edges and a nice tan head. The aroma is molasses, very smooth coffee, raisin, prune, and sweet chocolate. The flavor is an extremely complex and smooth coffee. I was skeptical about whether using finer coffee would make any noticeable difference in the beer, but it really does. Beyond the coffee flavors lie robust raisin, plum, and chocolate notes. It develops a somewhat ashy, green bitterness thats hard to tell whether its coming from coffee or hops. The finish is roasty and floral, leaving and aftertaste of coffee and just a touch of iodine. The oats lend a very smooth, slightly chewy mouthfeel that is perfect for this beer. Quite a tasty brew.

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2010 16.9oz bottle $15.99 Julios Liquors. Pours extremely dark liquid with dark foam. Leaves a dark lacing. In other words, this is quite dark! Chocolate, coffee, vanilla - its all in there and more. Absolutely no alcohol taste As a fan of imperial stouts this might be the best I have ever had. On a side note - it was only after I drank this that I learned it was made from coffee beans crapped out by weasels. I find myself now wanting to try a cup of coffee made from these beans which is something I doubt I would have considered before drinking this one. Could just be the 16 ounces of 10.9% talking here.

[march 18, 2009]

Big thanks to Tronraner for sharing this one. Pours near black with a very nice head. Loads of coffee is very obvious in the nose, but it is more juicy than sharp and roasty. Chocolate, oats, and ash are here as well. The palate is not giant, but just right for what weve got here. Lingering bittersweet, fruity coffee is the highlight of this one. Notes of vanilla wafers, cedar, and chocolate oats are also present. This is really a tasty treat.

Dark brown pour, smooth and viscous with a tall khaki head. Big coffee nose, like fresh espresso and coffee ice cream. Silky palate, thick body. Very well balanced throughout, not much to the acidity from the coffee but enough hops to keep it in check. Roasted malts pull dark chocolate and a soft earthy note. Really top notch in every way.

Bottle at Eulogy Belgian Tavern shared with puzzl and feedmecookies.  Deep brown beer with a thin tan head.  Aroma is loaded with soft herbal coffee aroma.  Fairly prominent heavy licorice character with a salty sort of roastiness.  Earthy and coffeeish.  Sweet and thick with a very syrupy palate and a fairly boozy component.  This is a big monster of a beer.  Big and loaded with coffee, but not enough to hide the fact that this is a big imperial stout.  I like it, but these really big beers kind of bore me a little bit.
Bottle thanks to Robert. Poured black with tan head. Aroma is coffee and roasted malt. Taste is similar with some toffee and chocolate. Really nice beer.

Bomber from AgentSteve shared by Odeed. Nose of coffee, chocolate, caramel, prunes, bubblegum, and some light hoppiness. Opaque dark brown with rusty edges and a medium cinnamon tan head. Flavor of chocolate, coffee, light bitterness, and some toffee. Silky body with a lightly bitter finish.

(bottle for agent steve)dark brown body with a foamy brown head that leaves nice lacing on the glass.the aroma is a complex mix of oatmeal,chocolate,coffee,roasted malts,and alcohol.the flavor is much of the same with the alcohol hiddena nd some powdered cocoa notes.palate is damn smooth.this is some serious shit.no pun intended.

Bottle shared by alexsdad06.

A - Poured a dark brown color with a large frothy brown head that lasted with excellent lacing.

S- Moderate to heavy roasted chocolate, caramel and alcohol aroma.

T - Heavy bittersweet roasted black coffee malty flavor with a heavy bittersweet and small alcohol bite finish of long duration.

M - Full body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation.

D - This is a standout beer.

Bottle kindly brought by Ole R
Lovely head, pitch black beer.
Strong coffee aroma, a hint of weasel, perhaps.
Dry cocoa, complex coffee aroma. Almost citrus sharpness, but this is blended well with the rest. Dry mouth feel in the tail.

Rich, roasty coffee dominates the aroma on this one. Lots of sweet chocolate, followed by the cat shit coffee, with a bit of bitterness in the end. There was an odd fruity aspect to this, perhaps from the coffee bean? Pretty good, but there are plenty of local Coffee Stouts that are as good and better. Certainly wasnt worth  my 17 bucks for a 500ml.

500 ml bottle. Pitch black. Medium-sized light beige head. Dark caramel aroma with hints of licorice. Dark chocolate. Thick mouthfeel with delicate flavours. Lots of rich choclate and coffee. Wonderfully balanced. I love the texture. It is just fantastic. Very complex. Slightly acidic, but that is likely because of the dark roasted malts. Creamy. There is also a bit of piney hops, but because of the richness it hides in the background. A winner.

Heavily chalky creamed espresso, gritty, earthy, extremely muddy and clouded aroma... the soil/earth character seems to mute any vibrancy of the coffee, and the chalkiness seems to cloud what may be a wonderfully rich dry/bitter chocolate note.  Instead the entire nose is muted, numbed, muddled and sort of messy.  Nothing seems to change when it hits the mouth - muddy, cloudy, soil-rich, earthy, and altogether messy.  Absolutely nothing stands out in this beer, the yeast seems to dampen and neutralize almost every good quality (roast, chocolate, coffee, cream) that the beer suggests it has hidden somewhere.  No major flaws at all, but a wholly unremarkable coffee stout.

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2009 Bottle... C&PsLYFO Throwdown... This beer rocks!... Black ale with a small, creamy, beige head. Good retention. Cocoa nibs, charcoal, smoke and espresso are the components of the aroma that stand out the most. Full-bodied with a velvety mouthfeel and gentle carbonation. The flavor is luxuriant and very espresso and chocolate-forward with a soothing hug of alcohol. The finish is burnt, boozy, and then dry.  Video  = http: //homepage.mac.com/maltajo/RATEBEER/iMovieTheater1 html  Thanks a million to mcbackus for bringing this world class offering to the Throwdown!

Bottle shared by Marcus. Very hazy and opaque dark brown color with a decent tan head. Aromas of coffee and dark malt. Full bodied with creamy carbonation. Flavor primarily of coffee and really dark toasted malt. It has a light dark toasted  malt flavor. Its sweet, but not obnoxiously so. Really tasty.
This black ale poured with a decent tan head and a coffee aroma. There is lots of coffee and toffee in the flavor. This is a very good beer.

Bottle from the Otown throwdown.  Mckbackus is the poop hero!  Black as hell with aroma of sweet chocolate, coffee, roasted malts and MORE coffee.  Flavor is so freaking smooth with such delicious coffee and choclate and damn did I mention this was good?

Thanks to roberto for sharing!. Nice toffee colored head, dark in color. Nice coffee aroma. Tons of roasted malts, just a touch of coffee. Lots of chocolate. Sweetness to it, but an aftertaste of bitterness to it. Dry finish. Good texture. Overall nice beer.
FRO Throwdown: Weasel poop woohoo! Black, tight layer of foam.Strong coffee with touches of caramel and chocolate milk. Creamy palate even! Big caramel chocolate mocha flavor.

Courtesy mcbackus.  Pours jet black with a small light tan head.  Thenose is of dark toasted malts, a little toffee, and bits of chocolate and and vanilla as well.  the flavor is very roasty, morseo than in the nose.  Lots of chocolate and coffee notes allaround.  Even hints of some sweet toffe or caramel in the finish.  Pretty full bodied, with a little heat left onthe palate.  maybe a touch overrated, but definitely top quality.

Sampled at C&P Otown Throwdown, big thanks to McBackus! Deep thick black pour with a creamy tan head. Huge chocolate malt, dark fruit and coffee aroma. Dark fruit chocolate and coffee taste. Well balanced and very drinkable for such a big beer. Awesome.

500 ml bottle from Orland Park Binnys. Pours pitch black with small tan head. Aroma is espresso, roasted malt, chocolate and dark fruits. Flavor is strong with espresso and roasted oats and malt, chocolate, dark fruits and some booze. Perfect mouthfeel and balance for a coffee stout. Liked this much better than Beer Geek Breakfest. Terrific brew and best Imperial Stout I have had in a long time. Expected a lot with high price tag and it exceeded my expectations.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2009 Pours a pitch black color with a quickly disappearing head.  Huge coffee aroma, nutty, some oats, and a hint of alcohol.  Slightly sticky body but silky in the mouth, sweet with a strong coffee taste.  Very malty, bitter chocolate finish. Top notch.

I was a little worried about this one seeing what it was made of but wow this was excellant with lots of coffee and chocolate that poured a black thick oily mess with a small tan head and was very smooth overall a very enjoyable beer.CHEERS!

Bottle from City Beer in SF.  This is the best poop-based beverage Ive ever had!  And that is saying something.  After drinking this, I wish I could shovel weasel crap into my mouth by the truckload.  Pours an oily black with a tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, roast, vanilla, and of course coffee.  Flavor is top-notch.  Lots of roast and coffee, bitter cocoa, and maybe even a little dark fruit.  No fecal matter detectable.  Rounds out incredibly well in the end with a full, satisfying mouthfeel.

Pours an oily black color with a small but dense tan head. Chocolate, molasses, dark roast, and even some creme brulee. Thick as hell with tons and tons bitter coffee a the start and quite a lot of sweet chocolate behind that. As it warms I get some raisins  as well. Creamy mouthfeel. Very good.

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2009 Poured a dark opaque black with a massive 3 finger medium brown head.  The aroma was not nearly as intense as I was expecting with understated notes of dark chocolate, vanilla, and roasted coffee beans.  Flavor is more of what I anticipated: intense, fresh brewed coffee, very dark chocolate, bitter roasted malt, and just a hint of mineral and caramelized banana at the end.  Coffee and bitter chocolate linger on the palate rounding out the experience.  This beer is also extremely silky and smooth on the palate, with only a hint of alcoholic burn.  A fine effort, although there are other coffee stouts I prefer.

This beer lived up to the hype. Aroma was so so. The usual mix of dark chocolate and coffee. Pour was perfect. A deep dark black with a pillowy dark tan head of about 2 fingers sitting on top. Taste was full, thick and chewy. The coffee flavor in this beer was amazing. Strong and bitter with the dark chocolate battling for dominance. Great carbonation for an impy and a delicious chocolatey thick aftertaste. I love those civetcats for shitting this out.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Pouring an opaque, inky, pitch black, the body is crowned with a thick, lasting head of light brown foam.  Showing some viscosity upon a swirl of the glass, a sheety wash slowly meanders back towards the surface, leaving sticky, jagged ribbons of lacing behind.  It looks like a menacing, serious imperial stout, considerably heavier than the Beer Geek Breakfast.  Rich and fully roasty, the nose shows massive coffee character, with freshly roasted dark beans clearly being the primary focus.  Bitter dark cacao and carefully burnt caramel provide ample malt backbone to stand up to the huge coffee roast.  The flavor is smooth and well blended, coffee and earthen hops pushing it to the brink of intense bitterness before the choco-caramel sweetness pulls it just back over the edge.  There are hints of anise and perhaps some deeply buried dark fruit, but this one is all about bitter roast and chocolate.  The mouthfeel is big, almost full in fact, finishing dry and roasty.  This is a mighty fine beer.  Not top 50 material, in my opinion, but a delicious coffee imperial nonetheless.

Tasted courtesy of Wee Heavy SD.  Thanks.  Black with a creamy brown head.  This one is a lot like Black but not as thick or sweet.  Great roasty, chocolate, espresso, and grain aroma and taste. Nice buttery mouth feel.  A really outstanding beer.

Nose is soft -- easy coffee smell. A bit of chocolate, but definitely coffee. Viscous on the palate - thick like a Goose Island Bourbon County Stout. Chocolate, but smoothed out with an oatmeal undertow. Smoooooothe. I expected a stronger coffee taste, but its so mellow and plays a great supporting role.

Rating 2400, Bottles via trade.  Shared at the BA Decadence 07 release, shared with many ratebeerians and the brewers at Alesmith.  Pours black with a light brown head.  Nose is full of big coffee punch, some roastyness and chocolate. Taste is quite roasty, with sweet chocolate, coffee, really rich, overall somewhat less than expected.  This beers is cool but has nothing whatsover on Alesmith the Shit.  nada.  But its still good and im glad I had it.

Bottle. Thick creamy tan head on top of a pitch black body. Head is leaving brown lacing in the glass. Complex roasty aroma with notes of caramel, lots of coffee, chocolate and some liquorice. Thick creamy body. Wow! The flavour is so intense! Off course lots of coffe but also some sweet malt that really works good with the bitterness. I also love the chocolate and the tiny saltyness I catch. This is truly a masterpiece. Thank you so much Mikkel for making such great beers!

Crushed with CarytheDude.  I can honestly say as an Imperial Stout guy that this beer, as good as it may be, is not among the type in its style.  Although, I must admit  I feel quite ecstatic drinking weasel feces with a smile on my face.  Great appearance, decent flavor, wonderful palate, and an overall delight.

Crushed with Jakebra.  I cant believe I just drank something a weasel poopty peupty pantsed.  Roasty nose is very nice, with minimal coffee and some sour notes.  Expected more weasel poop on the nose.  Flavor is incredibly pleasant, a nice silky mouthfeel, with great roasty coffee and dark chocolate.  The finish is gorgeous.  A huge rush of bittering hops and bitter coffee that lasts and lasts and lasts.  A very good beer, but top 50 I doubt it.  One very cool concept, and they pulled it off about as well as they could have.

[Bottle] shared at Skyviews Lex/Larp Cellars Farewell. Pours black with a smallish tan head. Aroma is chocolate, coffee, and a touch of astringent roasted malts. Flavor is awesome coffee, chocolate, and roasted malts. Absolutely velvety mouthfeel and carbonation.

Pours thick rich black with mocha head.  Aroma of strong roasted oily bitter coffee, roasted malt, dark chocolate, licorice, and slight dark fruit.  A little bit of alcohol astringency in the nose- I cant wait to see what this is like after some aging.  Flavor is the perfect melding of oily strong coffee and rich dark chocolate notes with roasty malts and touches of creaminess.  Slight sweetness and an untouchable creamy palate make this one nearly perfect.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2012 Bottle at home Thanks to Fonefan for this...Deep black ... Thin dark short livedbrown head ... huge coffee roast malt nose ... big coffee hit up front ... deep smooth roast ... light sweetness on top of the smooth coffee ... light coffee roast bitterness... some dark cherries ... quite a bit of jammieness thats really quite delightful.... light hop hit in background ... good mouthfeel ... chocolate comes a bit more prominant over time as it sits out ... 3.8


oh this is great ... on tap at brewdog ... nice chocolate malts ... dark roask ... big chocolate ... soooth silky chocolate ... dark malts ... chocolate roast nice ... 4.3

dark black ... big tan head ... huge roast ... light cofee ... light hop ... big chocolate front ... deep roast ... big smooth coffee dark sweet and rich ... nice body 4.0
TK2
deep black ... thin tan head ... rich roast nose and big cofffee .. sweet roast malt frint ... big bitter coffee linger ... little licorice 3.7

Tk3 
deep black ... thin tan head ... huge  soft coffeee ... light roast malt nose ... ligth bitter coffee ... sweet roast ... big chocolate ... hint of spirit though there none in it ... 3.7

Bomber.  Enormously high hopes for this one and as such it falls victim to its own hype.  Aroma of chocolate, espresso, and alcohol, some slight fruity malt.  Pours pitch with a dark brown head, rocky and aggressive with good legs, looks, as the other Michael says, "like mousse on the top."  Taste is too-raw alcohol and espresso dumped into a thick, full chocolate stout, but one which lacks the roasty notes and general rounded harmony of the best of the best.  In the end, I really wanted to taste some coffee in this sucker, whether the beans had passed through a civet or not.This is a very good beer, but not transcendent, a height which Mikkeller has clearly reached with other brews.  Its also very young.

more complex than beer geek bruch both in its aroma and flavour.  Pours jet black with minimal head.  Aroma is more subtle than brunch 1for 1, includes mocha, chocolatey aroma and in the flavour.  Flavour also contained slight sweetness.  Same great mouthfeel  Up there with expedition for my favourite imperial stout.  Awesome job
Poured from a 50cl bottle.  Dark Brown with light brown head.  Nose of coffee and chocolate.  Sweet taste with subtle sweet aroma.  Excellent

Bottle shared by Turd. Snap, this is good.  Thin brown bubbly head on top of a black pour.  Sweet chocolate nose.  Think mocha syrup.  Earthy as well, though, which really keeps it interesting.  Tangy, too.  Tasty.  Really, really tasty.

Pros: Excellent appearance, natural carbonation - long lasting foam, tremendous purity, full mouth feel.  Not brash for being so young (unlike Black Hole.)   Complex, concentrated.  Will mature in the bottle.

 

Cons: While the aroma is pretty nice, its not as powerful as Id like.  

 

I plan on putting some away.
looks great with a nice sized head, best smelling "coffee" stout i have had and best tasting as well, worth the price if you can find it try it.

The bottle looks good, the beer in the glass could not look better. Deep, deep black, very brown head. Starts very intense and complex malty, notes of strong coffee, liquorice and some chocolate. Well balanced, warming finish, soft as silk. A bit sweet aftertase. An incredible good beer!

Thank you yespr for this bottle!

Bottle. From Jessup plaza. Poured a jet black color with a small brown head. Aroma is strong coffee and chocolate. Very thick mouthfeel on this one. Very smooth and drinkable. Lots of alcohol on the back of the mouth. This is great. Very good.

Bottle from Ölbutikken.
Pours black with a brown head.
Malts, coffe, soy and hops.
Realy big taste!

Appearance is a definate 5. Dark dark brown with a huge froathing brown head. Delicate dark desert chocolate aroma with notes of coffee, vanilla and wood. Flavor is delicate aswell, not overwhelming, which is nice. Makes it extremly drinkable, especially for a 10+ abv. Soft oily palate and medium complex bitter notes, sleightly roasted but mainly its coffee/chocolate bitter. Awsome!
Bottle at 3 Små Rum, Göteborg. Coffee aroma, cocoa powder, licorice and salt. Malty licorice flavor, cocoa, coffee notes. Salty and spicy. Huge body.

Bottle @ 3-små rum Göteborg: 
Black colour, creamy brown head. Aroma of coffee,dark choclate,salt-lakris,pine.
Flavor has almost the same complex mix,creamy mouth feeling, medium to full body,long fruity/caramelly finish. This was werry nice!!

Bottle. Look: Black. Thick brown head. Smell: Hops. Milk chocolate. Coffee. Smokeiness. Taste: Oaky vanilla. Coffee. Dark chocolate. Vinous. Hop bitterness and roasted thing going on in the aftertaste. Overall: Superb stout! But i think Beer Geek Breakfast is better, this one has too many flavors sometimes... still lovely though.

Huge chocolate head that sticks around for awhile. This beer is dark black, and it looks very nice. The head doesnt fade away quickly, which is nice. Nice sweet pungent aroma with a great roast smell. This beer smells great, but tastes better. The beer has an awesome palate to it. This beer has an awesome silky and creamy texture.Ridiculous roast flavor with a nice coffee aftertaste. Sweet flavors touch your tongue and a nice bitterness follows the sweet, roast, and coffee flavors. Sweet malts are a great part of the beer, and make this a fantastic stout. I love that this stout has an awesome balance, and an even better palate than most imperial stouts I have tried.

Bottle @ Beer Hunters, Pori. Intensily black, totally disappearing cocoa head.  Huge espresso nose, little salty liquorice and tar, faint soy sauce and barnyard even. Syrupy espresso flavor, some tar, molasses, lingering roasty espresso finish. Feels kinda messy, same as the normal Beer Geek. Full bodied, lush easy palate. A very good coffee impy, but far from divine. Shared this with TBone, who suggested it wasnt totally in shape, and it definitely wasnt as smooth as I had hoped.

500. Thanks, Maria! Pours jet black with a dense, creamy tan head. Looks oily and sloshy in the glass. Huge nose of coffee, dark fruit, booze, and chocolate. Thick, creamy body. Somewhat sticky. Huge coffee flavors. Some chocolate. A little bit of dark fruit there. Long fry roasty finish.

(50cl bottle, thanks ygtbsm) Medium brown head atop black body with brown edges.  Aroma is moderately sweet, coffee, bittersweet chocolate, some roast.  Taste is moderately sweet, coffee/roast.  Sticky medium-full body.

200th rating.  I chose to taste an new and highly acclaimed brew from Mikkeller to launch myself into the 200s.  Aroma is of coffee, subtle chocolate, earthy aromas resonate with the malt and coffee to create and extremely balanced aroma that makes me incredibly excited to quaff it.  The exquisite quality of the coffee and the perfect amount of dark rich malts make this something really special.  The oatmeal smooths out the mouthfeel to create a silky smooth liquid that i dont want to leve my mouth.  Absolutely breathtaking, Im delighted that this is my 200th

Courtesy of Jblauvs- thanks Jamie. Pours like squid ink with magnanimous tan head. Aroma is riddled with earthy espresso, fudge, cream (I creamed my pants by the way), and gratuitous roast. Flavor is in the running for the most wonderful substance Ive ever quaffed. Roast hits like a freight train, with the deep espresso notes following and lingering like heaven. Chocolate is delicious, balance is unparalleled. Palate is thick, rich, sliky, and creamy. Every facet of delivery is covered. Incredible example of the style, and a brew that deserves the utmost respect. Expertly crafted- one of the best Imperial Stouts Ive had to date.

pours pitch black with a brown head- incredible. Aroma is otherworldly- tons of coffee, but incredibly earthy- can smell the difference between the civet coffee and normal coffee in impys. Lots of chocolate, creaminess, and heavy roasted malt. Flavor is also phenomenal- heavy coffee, cream, chocolate. Palate is better than almost any beer ive had- rich, smooth- I cant even express this beer in the proper words. Absurdly good.

Huge creamy dark lasting head. Deep black body. Nose of coffee and fruits. Aroma of lots of coffee and toasted and roasted malt. Heavy alcohol. Full body with a creamy and sticky texture. Bitter finish. The flavor is heavy sweet and moderate bitter. A very good and powerfull imperial stout - but also expensive.

Bottled at Tre små rum.
Black with a small, beige head.
Dry, slightly harsh cocoa-aroma with light coffee.
Very soft and smooth palate.
Chocolate, coffee and licorice in abundance.

500ml bottle from west lakeview... pretty good looking black pour with a fluffy and considerable light brown head... vibrant roasted malt profile, stong coffee aromatice, and a nice chocolate base....semi-sweet chocolate flavor with an assertive roasted malt component.  really liked the way the flavor remained bold and carried through to the very end.  carbonation on the lighter side so that it didnt interfere with the bold flavor.  really enjoyable even with the high price tag.

Thanks nbuttler11. Pours a dark thick black that allows a tiny amount of light on the edge. Head is a very nice two finger creamy chestnut brown. The nose shows nice coffee, prominent coffee/chocolate roastyness, mild alcohol, nice balance of sweetness and roast from the grain, mild mocha aroma. Flavor is more roasty than I expected, prominent from the grain and coffee, bakers chocolate, molasses, mild alcohol, very nice flavor. Thick velvety mouthfeel with a prominent bitterness and warming finish. Lovely.

Pours a deep brownish black with a large brown head. Aroma is coffee, malt, chocolate. Very bitter coffee flavor almost dry and chalky with a little sweetness and a bitter finish. I drank poop and it wasnt all that bad, awesome!

Thanks to rustychiles for the share. Pours pitch black with minimal head. Very acrid bitter coffee aroma. Taste is lots of dark fruit, some nice coffee and roast tastes. Aftertaste is quite bitter with lots of acid coming off of the coffee I think. Im making the coffee tastes sound bad, but they really are quite pleasant and work well with the overall beer. However, it just comes with some acrid flavors that I have to mention. Overall, nowhere near as good as one for one, but better than normal beer geek. Solid offering.

500ml Bottle:  Aroma of chocolate, coffee, piney hops, alcohol, slight roasted/burnt malts, and slight citrus.  Poured pitch black in color with a small, dark brown head that diminished but lasted around the edges.  Opaque.  Flavor is medium sweet and light to medium bitter.  Tastes of piney hops, burnt malts, chocolate, coffee, caramel, light alcohol, and some roasting.  Medium to full body.  Thick, viscous, sticky, coating texture.  Soft carbonation.  Bitter-sweet, chocolate, coffee, and hop finish is a bit sticky.

50cl bottle thanks to YGTBSM.   Black with a tan, almost grey head.   Big roasted malt and rich coffee aroma.   Smells like good, fresh coffee, which Ive missed in coffee aromas lately.   The flavor is a lot of coffee, with a powerful roast, lots of bitterness, light alcohol, and a smooth, dry finish.   Full, super creamy body.   Really powerful, but the coffee, hops, and malt strike a nice balance.   Great stuff, and satisfying to a coffee lover when so many coffee beers actually dont greatly appeal to me.

Im the Weaz and nobody beats me!  Another awesome bottle shared by weazmacgee.  Pours thick black with a nice tan head. Nose is coffee and cooca. Flavor has molasses, mocha milkshake. Silky smooth mouthfeel that is just the way I like it.  The coffee is less pronounced in this one than the Beer Geek Breakfast and the sweeter milk chocolate and dark fruit flavors come through more. Alcohol is pretty well hidden, rare for these high gravity Danish brews. Thanks for sharing Ethan!

Bottle thanks to bu11zeye.  poured black with a chocolate brown head.  aroma of chocolate, coffee, and dark roasts.  flavor was much the same.  this was extremely balanced.  full body, low carb, had some dryness in it as well.  i love me some poop beer.

Nobody does it like The Weaz! Bomber shared by emacgee - thanks, rocker! Very thick and oily looking pour, with a nice cocoa head and some lively carbonation. Both the nose and the flavor contain far more molasses and chocolate notes than the regular Beer Geek brew (which I sill prefer to this one, I think). Palate is slightly thinner than I thought, given the appearance, but its delightfully smooth and silky. Enough hops to complement the dominant flavors and give the beer real fullness, balance. The flavors really linger on the palate in just the way youd hope given a beer like this. I still want a bit more coffee bitterness from this, but its a great beer.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2009 Bottle. My danish beer #1500!
Creamy almost darkbrown excellent fully lasting head. Black colour. Initial fantastic hoppy aroma fading a little bit to quickly leaving a powerfull nice roasted/chocolate note. Exstremely powerfull complex flavor. Almost astringent bitterness and lots of vanilla. Not too dominated by coffee. Exstremely long great finish. Excellent to perfect palate. Truly great.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */, Brommaplan, Stockholm. Black colour, small brown head. Aroma is very sweet alcoholic, malty, licoracy and chocolaty. Also some slight hints of coffee and smoke as it warms up. Flavour is quite much the same, but the balance seems to be out there still. Not that impressed. Probably needs some age.

(bottle shared by Skyview) Pours dark brown with a tan head.  I didnt find the aroma to be particularly appealing, there was dominant dark roasted coffee, smoke, and some sweeter hints of milk chocolate.  The taste was rather sweet, with plenty of chocolate to begin with and a hint of vanilla that then switched over to a roasted coffee finish that lingered well after drinking. There was also some alcohol present in the flavor. The mouthfeel was full and silky.

Picked up a single 500 ml bottle at Heritage Liquors in Maplewood, MN. Pours a near opaque black brew the a thin tan head that slowly dissipates to a thin creamy tan top and excellent lacing. Aroma of Toasted dark malt, some light coffee, dark chocolate, a hint of vanilla, oatmeal and honey. Taste is full bodied, very little carbonation, flavors of thick toasted dark malt, semi-sweet coffee, dark chocolate, a hint of cream, vanilla and some sugar, Finish is thick, silky with a mild coffee and dark chocolate aftertaste. Very impressive.

Blackish in color with a nice looking tan head - easily one of the prettiest pours Ive seen.  Aroma has a gentle coffee aroma with some milky and strong dark chocolates with a mild roast.  Flavor is really nice with an incredible coffee flavor that is so smooth.  High quality chocolate covered espresso beans with some gentle vanilla and sugar come to mind....Dynamite feel that goes on for days.  Wow.  This is the coffee beer Ive always wanted - non coffee lovers often cringe at any coffee beer, but this could even make them happy.  The "Weasel" coffee is so smooth without any excessive bitterness or astringency, that the resulting coffee contributes so much.   This one rules!

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2009 Bottle 50 cl. Pours completely opaque black with a dense and lacing light brown head. Aroma of sweet vanilla and sweet burned malts. Full-bodied, again sweet vanilla, chocolate and burned coffee accents with an extremely pleasant and smooth mouthfeel. Lightly malt bitter finish - but stil smooth, smooth, smooth. Yummy. 280209

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2009 Bottle. Pours near black with a billowing brown head. Roasted coffee aroma, a hint of hops and some sweeter notes of chocolate on the background. The flavor has a huge roasted coffee flavor, with a light dark chocolate sweetness. Roasted coffee and hoppy bitterness seems to linger in the mouth forever. Definitely good, but not earth shattering.

Wow loved this. Nice hop nose and the flavor was incredible.Nice easy to drink and smooth roasted malts coming together with a really nice balance. Smooth and creamy. This was my favorite of the evening and I had it beside a BA Speedway.I will be picking more of this up for sure. Thanks Marsiblursi...

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2009 2009-08-24, bottle, 7-4-8-4-15=38Black color. The aroma is not impressive, with very light vanilla. The flavor is well smooth, with a good mix of chocolate, caramel and light-sweet liquorice. The final is dominated by the chocolate. Good.2009-02-20, bottle at Ølbaren, CopenhagenBlack color. The aroma is both breadish and burnt. Medium body, it has a very good balance of chocolate, caramel, roasted malt, coffee and cream. The best feature of this Stout is its creamy character.

The head that you get at first is dark tan and fades slowly but not before creating an interesting lattice work structure that is fun to watch dissipate.  The aroma is pretty incredible too and dominated by roasted chocolate and bitter coffee. The flavor is mostly a smooth roast coffee flavor with some chocolate notes dancing in the background. The bitterness is a little much and  the hops probably could have been toned down a bit. The finish is pretty much a grassy hop flavor.  Full bodied and a great straight forward impy stout.

This beer glugged out of the bottled thickly and into the glass it left a large brown head. The flavor is awesome: chocolate, coffee with a wonderfully creamy mouthfeel. Its thick, in the best sort of way. Its simply a world-class imperial stout.

Yes!  This beer is the shit!!  Bottle pours pitch black with tan head.  Aromas are simply amazing.  Strong coffee, chocolate, and more coffee.  Has a medium heavy mouthfeel.  Flavor follows the nose.  Has a strong coffee characteristic, a creaminess, dark chocolate, and finishes with brown sugar.  I could drink this all night.  Its such a wonderful brew.  I may have to break the bank and pick up another bottle or two.  Wow.

Bottled 10,9% @Pikkulintu. 
Opaque black-brown color, good espresso head. Strong coffeish, licorice aroma - typical Beer Geek Breakfast nose :) Full-bodied. Coffee, licorice in the flavor, soft palate (not too burned). Long toasted atfertaste. Balanced, enjoyable. Great Oatmeal stout and hands down the best new beer Ive had in 2009 so far.

Earthy, fruit(raspberry, pomegranate), coffee on the nose.  Toasted. Cheese.  Tons of Flavor! The coffee taste is of espresso, with east african character.  Dark Belgian chocolate, toffee, and brown sugar settle round your mouth.  A good bitter finish of spicy hops. Fantastic!

I had a sample of this post-NOTB last weekend (thanks, Nelson!), and Im relaxing with a 16.9oz bottle from Capones tonight. Pours very deep brown, capped with a moderate sized mocha head. Rich espresso aroma, malt, milk chocolate and brown sugar. Flavor begins with chocolate malt and earth, with espresso soon hitting the palate and adding depth. The coffee flavor hangs out for a long finish, complimented by a subtle herbal character and milt citric hops. Full bodied, with a smooth mouthfeel. Really nice stout.

Bottle.   Pours midnight black with a 2 finger mocha colored head that leaves fantastic lacing.  The nose is espresso, burnt malt and chocolate.  The taste is strong black coffee, ashy cocoa, molasses and light soy.  Medium creamy and lively mouthfeel.  ABV is nicely hidden.  As a strong black coffee lover, I really enjoyed this one.  Its the shit!

Black pour with minimal tan head. Very strong aroma I could detect from a few feet a way. It mellows a bit, mostly very strong coffee, roasty, and chocolate. Flavor is very strong coffee with a roasted malt, some sweetness. Lot of chocolate mouse and dark chocolate flavors, and finishes dry and bitter with more strong coffee. Mouthfeel is nice and full and there is only the slightest alcohol burn in the back of the throat. Pretty awesome.

Courtesy of gunhaver. Pours deep dark brown to almost black with brown edges and thin mocha head. It has a timid aroma that seems to be hiding away in my glass and giving just glimpses of roasted malts, molasses and chocolate malts. It quickly becomes impossible to smell anything out of this beer. The taste is no where near timid with rich sweet maltiness, velvety chocolate and molasses all coming together nicely. Nearing midway caramel shows up with solid coffee notes in tow to join in with the chocolate, roasted malts and molasses. The roasty malts and coffee join forces to help dry the flavor out into the finish and after taste. Solid flavor and disappointing aroma.

Bottled at Sorbon, Stockholm.  Very black with small beige head. Rich aroma of coffee and licorice. Sweet and full bodied, honey rounds of a solid body, coffee is ever present. Sweetness reaches a level where it starts to clash with bitterness, but chocolate softens it. Feels a bit more edgy and less pleasat than most Beer Geek stouts.

Bottled at Sorbon, Bromma, Sweden. Pours out in a thick opaque black colour with a small creamy pale brown foam. Rich, solid aroma of coffee, nougat, cocoa, hay and alcohol. Full-bodied with touches of black coffee, nougat, roasted malts, sweet licorice, hay and mild smoke. Long chewy rounded finish of dark coffee, chocolate-sauce, spices and mild alcohol.

50 cl bottle from Plaza Liquors - Pours a dark brown color with a three finger thick dark tan head which faded pretty quick with a few swirls of the glass.  Light lacing.  Aroma is roasted malt, coffee, herbs, and a touch of alcohol.  Flavor is roasted malt, hints of dark chocolate, faint smoke, and light  coffee.  Finish is a touch dry and bitter, but smooth.  Medium to full body.  A nice good beer.  Just not worth the $16 I paid for it.

Bottle purchased at Papago.  Pours obsidian with a firm mocha head.  Permeates the smell of dark roasted coffee.  Features balanced notes of espresso, chestnut, bakers cocoa, malt, molasses, and cream.  Supremely smooth and well-crafted.  I seemed to miss the oatmeal, but certainly think this is the best beer Ive had from Mikkeller and definitely understand why its shot so rapidly to the top ranks.

Pours black as death with a medium head.  Good aroma of coffee and roasted malts.  Strong roasted malt, chocolate and coffee flavor.  A very little bit of spearmint.  Some pine hops on the finish.  Thick as molasses.  Delicious!

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2011 Visually stunning!!!  The body of this beer truly absorbs every ounce of light around it; the blackest of blacks.  Enormous cotton-like latte-colored head; exploding bubbles making holes like that in swiss cheese.  Pungent aroma of fresh coffee, toasted nuts, and bitter chocolate.  Molasses, brown sugar, intense dark roasted Starbucks, and Godiva.  Creamy, sticky, and filling.  The 10.9% is invisible....this is some good shit!!!  BUMP!!!

Rated to celebrate my rating number 12,300. Bottled. A pitch black beer with a huge dark brown head. The aroma is sweet though with an acicic note of coffee, hops, and bitter chocolate, combined with citrusy notes. The flavor is sweet with strong notes of roasted malt, great coffee, alcohol, citrusy hops, and dark bitter chocolate - everything is powerful in this beer, leading to a bitter quite hoppy and citrusy finish, but also with underlying strong notes of roasted malt and coffee.

Thanks to Tertons for sharing at EBF.  Pours a nice deep black with a really cool fluffy lasting head. Aroma is rich dark roasted coffee beans, espresso with a dark chocolate earthy coffee kick.  Real full rich coffee flavor- tons of chocolate malts, and dark bittersweet earthy chocolate nutty notes form the coffee- big and sweet without being cloying, nice earthy feel and smooth and rich in the end.  Great coffee impy stout.

Well I love coffee! And God do I love this beer!
Creamy and delicious with a slight bitter aftertaste.
Couldn´t drink 2 in one night though!
The boys have done it again.
Just great.

Bottle shared by that great Weasel farmer nbutler11.  My overall impression is that the texture was like a big, giant milk stout.  Aroma is hellishly dark coffee and burnt dark chocolate.  Flavors of the same, plus an interesting anise interaction.  A little under-spiced for me, and rather lacking on the oatiness.  Still, quite dark, quite smooth, and exceptionally relaxing fare for an evening in front of the terra cotta oven.

Bottle shared by Tertons at EBF tasting.  Pours a black body with a tan head.  Big roasty coffee notes.  Sweet and oily with hints of lactose, licorice, and coffee beans.  Very roasty, my big turn off.

(Bottle at Pikkulintu. Helsinki, on 2009-02-24) Black. Small tan coloured head. Coffee, liquorice and roastedness in aroma. Full bodied, dry, and oily palate with medium carbonation. Coffee, liquorice, bitterness, some cream, roastedness and bit of sweetness in taste. Roastedness, coffee and bitterness in aftertaste.

Bottle thanks to bu11zeye.  The smell is great fresh ground coffee, nice roasted malts, dark and dried fruits.  The look is a very dark black with a decent tan colored head. The taste is malts, coffee, chocolate, and some really roasty goodness.

Pours a black color with a brown head.  Strong coffee aroma with some roasted malts, chocolate, dark fruits, and a little bit of alcohol.  Flavor is also strong of coffee with some roasted malts, chocolate, and dark fruits. Finishes slightly bitter with some alcohol warming.

opaque black with a syrupy appearance out of the bottle.  huge effervescent brown head overflows out of the glass.  large chunky yeast(i hope) particles.   coffee, chocolate, light hop aroma.  flavors of sweet robust chocolates, sugared coffee.   also so cinnamon anise christmas-like spice which i keep telling myself has something to do with cat crap.  medium to full bodied with a really smooth easy to drink palate.  alcohol is well hidden. this is great stuff.

courtesy of gunhaver
pours black with coffee like head.
Aroma is malty and coffee for a light bitter nose.
Taste roasted malts, coffee, chocolate and good presence of the alcohol.
Thick palate with notes of coffee and dark fruits for a light bitter finish.

Bottle courtesy of gunhaver. Pours black with a one finger mocha head that lasts leaving good lacing. Aroma of slightly acidic heavy roast coffee, roasted malt, chocolate, and a touch of caramel. Taste is the same as aroma. Medium full mouthfeel with a moderate amount of bitterness and slight acidity from the coffee. Very good.

Bottle, courtesy nbutler11. Pours pitch black, with a huge dark brown head and creamy lacing. Nose is spicy, with coffee, roast, some chocolate, cinnamon. Flavor is spicy, chocolatey, bitter tasty, tangy body. Unique. Smooth, drinkable, very balanced and tasty.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2009 Bottle.  Pours opaque black with a thick brown head.  I dont get how this one is different than any other coffee type stout.  The nose it quite roasty and full of coffee.  Sure, its tasty.  Lots of coffee and chocolate with a smooth bitterness.  Leave a licorice or anise after taste.  Thats a bit different.  Not special though.  Chewy body an silky mouthfeel.  I look at the score that Im giving this beer and it doesnt really fit with my comments.  When is said and done this is on par with Founders Breakfast Stout, Peche Mortel, and Speedway.

1pt .9oz bottle poured into a snifter.

The pour is gorgeous with a huge fluffy tan head on top of a pitch black body.  The head lingers as a big cap for the duration and leaves tons of lacing.

The aroma is massive with dominant smells of dark sweet malts and roasted coffee.  Neither dominates the other and make for an extremely well balanced nose.

I have to admit to being slightly biased as I love coffee infused beers, but, damn, the taste is extraordinary.  Its got the roasted coffee playing a prominent role but there is none of the bitterness that often goes along with it.  The sweet dark malts form a great backbone with some chocolate and licorice.  Hints of smoke linger in the finish along with a perfect coffee aftertaste.

The mouthfeel is nothing short of perfection.  Good carbonation combined with a heavier body produces the ideal velvety finish that you strive for.

Well, this just blew me away.  The look and aroma were pretty darn good, but after the first sip, I was hooked.  This is a truly exceptional beer - a perfectly balanced coffee stout.  Go get this now.

1pt .9 oz. bottle with thanks to pantanap!  Pours a dark black with a towering fluffy tan head, excellent retention and lacing.  The nose is more subtle than expected, but there is still a good amount going on; espresso, cold pressed coffee, chocolate, molasses, vanilla, some dark fruits, and some piney hops.  The flavor is more chocolate, espresso, vanilla, over-ripe dark fruits and a touch of piney hops.  A smooth and creamy palate.  Dont get me wrong, this is still a fine beer, but not on par with the regular BGB and 1for1.  Thanks Kan!

(500ml bottle)  Pours an opaque black body with a small brown head.  Aroma of coffee, roasted malt, and pine.  Flavor of roasted malt, coffee, hops (pine, earthy), and dark chocolate with a dry, bitter finish.
Very beefed up beer geek brew. Loads of intense coffe with a good foundation of other imperial stout goodies. Nothing I would want to drink every night but every second or so!

Bottle thanks to bu11zeye. Really been looking forward to this one. Pours a black dark reddish brown color with a reddish brown color. Decent lacing. Nose is bitter dark chocolate, burnt coffee, roasted beans, and espresso. Thick mouthfeel and long finish.

([email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */) deep darkbrown colour with huge head. first bottle was almost only alcohol and coffee. second bottle has hidden alcohol and become much better.. best brewed beer with cat shit!
Bottle thanks to bu11zeye. Black in color with a decent sized tan head. Aroma is heavy in coffee with some roasted malts, mud, and tobacco. Taste is of coffee, vanilla, dark fruits, and dirt.
bottle thanks to bu11zeye, deep black color with no head, great coffee nose with good viscosity on the swirl, flavor is a light oily chocolate and coffee, very smooth and balanced, impressive

# 1150.  16.9 oz bottle.  Pours a black color with a medium sized brown head.  Aroma of roasted malts, coffee beans, and chocolate.  Taste of roasted malt, coffee beans, chocolate and creamy expresso.

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2009 Glad I got to rate this before WeeHeavySD and Wetherel! Pours perfect deep brown with a pancake colored head that persists. Nose is mostly a zesty, tangy coffee along with chocolate, tobacco and leather. The flavor is the same with the alcohol hidden well. Smooth mouthfeel and lightly bitter finish.

Bottle. Body-opaque with a thick ring of bubbles, looks like a stout. Nose-clean grass, perfect coffee. Taste-steak seasoning, light citric acid, very clean, perfect cold pressed coffee, medium bitter, perfect sweetness, cold espresso. I dont think that I have ever had a beer with such perfect coffee flavor. I am not just saying this because this beer is all special because it comes form coffee shat out of a varmint, but this is a world class beer that should be held in the highest of regards.

Bottle shared thanks to TomDecapolis. Poured a dark black color, with brown edges, and an averaged sized tan head. The head quickly disappeared. Aromas of coffee, roast, and some chocolate. Nice coffee. Tastes of coffee, roast, vanilla, chocolate, and some dark fruits. I love coffee beers and expect coffee in them, and this one had it. Alcohol content well hidden.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2009 Rating number 1500 for me. The Wheeze thanks to bu11zeye. Thick motor oil pour that results in a large, very dark brown head. Upon swirling the body coats the glass with a brown film and settles back down to its blackness. Good lace left. Aroma is weasel ass...okay not really. Earthy and roasty with vanilla, grapes, and tons and tons of strong, spicy coffee. Taste is really very rich with coffee, vanilla, cocoa powder and chocolate. Very slick and mouthcoatingly syrupy body. Very nice. didnt notice if there was carbonation or not. Very good, but not quite a top 50 beer to me. Although I love Mikkeller (and Nogne for that matter), I really didnt think that Beer Geek Breakfast was any sort of world beating stout (although it was good). This is much better, but I can name some better coffee biased imperial stouts.

Pours opaque dark brown to black with a tan head. Coffee, dark chocolate and roast present in the aroma. Taste includes elements of roasted malt, coffee, vanilla and dry bitterness. Feels creamy to oily in the mouth. An admirable imperial stout from Mikkeller.

Poured an opaque black color with a medium sized, tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of roasted malts, coffee beans, vanilla, and a bit of cocoa.  Taste of vanilla beans, roasted malts, tobacco, coffee, dark fruits, vanilla, and a dry finish.

Bottle thanks to bu11zeye. Pours a used motor oil black with a brown/copper head. Aroma of coffee, dark roast, and baking chocolate. Flavor of coffee, baking chocolate, dark roast, with a nice roasty bitterness. Mouthfeel is a heavy body with medium carbonation. Overall, these Mikkeller beers are great! I love them!

Bottle.  Pours dark brown, almost black, with a nice big tan head, light lace.  Aroma of nice roasted malt and coffee. Taste is also very roasted, with vanilla, chocolate, lightly bitter notes.  Very solid and malty.  Finish is lightly bitter, though very smooth.  Again, very solid.  Mouth is creamy, somewhat dry, and also lightly carbonated.  Overall, a great imperial stout.  Im glad to have found this in my area.

Im hoping this beer will live up to the hype.  Dark brown pour with a tan head.  Good lacing.  Hazelnut, burnt coffee, cocoa, vanilla; just lots of maltiness.  Flavor is complex with accents of pepper to compliment the aroma components.  This has a nice warming feeling going down and the flavors really explode once I let this warm up.  The coffee is strong, but is well complimented by a myriad of other flavors.  The palate starts out smooth and finishes dry.  Worth the hype, however, I dont know if Ill be forking out the $15 too often.  Maybe again for a special occasion.  Great beer!  Actually Id like to see how this would stack up against Speedway, one of my favorite stouts.

50cl bottle.  Pours deep brown with a beautiful, creamy mocha head, a pleasure to watch.  Pretty strong charred coffee aroma, with smooth deep malt and vanilla accents.  Really creamy in the mouth, significantly better as it warms.  No harsh flavors, not overly roasty, a little chocolate with a very pleasant coffee hue.  Kind of thin mouthfeel.  One of the better imperial stouts out there, its not my favorite style, but this one is totally solid.

Pours a deep black with a small bubbly deep tan head that went away quickly.  Aroma of deep roasted malt, lots of coffee notes, vanilla, coffee, tobacco and chocolate. Flavor of smooth coffee notes, caramel, vanilla, oats, chocolate milkshake, roasty malt, earthy and lots of tobacco flavor.

Bottle.  Pours black with a thick, slowly rising dark chocolate colored head.  Aroma of roasted malt and coffee.  Flavor of rich roasted malt and coffee grounds.  Not as coffee-rich as I was expecting.  Certainly a well-made beer, but nothing about it really stands out to me.  Definitely good, not a wow-er.
8/4/8/4/16 (4.0/5)

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2009 Bottle. Black as night pour. Absolutely pitch with a thick, pillowy dark khaki head that eventually settles to a greyish/brown film. Musty and roasty aroma. Slightly salty. Plenty of dark, roasted malt and espresso. Bitter bakers chocolate and cocoa. The saltiness is just odd... Flavor has lots of coffee, roasted malt, salt and green pepper. Alcohol asserts itself on the finish. Dark chocolate notes come up as the beer warms. Fairly velvety palate. Mild carbonation. Fairly simple and straightforward coffee stout. Decent... but the 5th best beer in the world? Hardly.

UPDATED: OCT 1, 2009 Bottle (50 cl), shared with gnoff and deft at Haket, Göteborg, Sweden. Black with creamy beige/brown head. Roasted malt aroma with notes of coffee, dark chocolate, some caramel/sugar, and the typical Mikkeller green pepper. A bit salty finish. Liked the regular Beer Geek Brunch better.

Bottle 1 pt .9 fl oz (50 cl?) at Haket, Göteborg, Sweden.On February 18, 2009Shared with ekstedt and deftBlack color, brwon head. Salty, rosated, coffee, chocolate scent. Salty, alcohol, roasted, coffee taste. Initially qutie bad, but aftertaste is a lot better, really nice even. Nice smooth mouthfeel, medium dry bitterness.

Bottle, thanks to mixinnixon2000. Pours dark brown, with a large, brown head. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, hops, dark fruit, and vanilla. Flavor is coffee, dark fruit, chocolate, hops, roasted malt, and vanilla. Creamy body. This is fantastic.

500ml bottle. pours black with tan head forming around the rim. nose of rich hazelnut coffee notes, roasty and chocolately. flavors are nutty, dark chocolate, coffee, a very roasty and dry finish. med body, smooth, with no alcohol noticed. very tasty.

Bottle: Pours sludgy, fudgy and thick, opaque black with a frothing 3 finger head as it falls into the tulip glass. Nose of dark chocolate, coffee and vinous fruits. Incredible body, velvety, thick and rich, one of the best beers in the world, awesome.

Black colored with little dark brown head. Extremely rich aroma with roastiness, vanilla, chocolate, licorice and grassy hops. Near full bodied, velvety palate. Flavor is even richer and better with fine and balanced roasted vanilla note, aftertaste turns to hopped with some berries. Slightly sweet sticky palate, still excellently balanced brew with nice hops.

Bottle. Pours pitch black with a big dense dark brown head. 
Aroma is roasted coffee, dark fruit and dark chocolate. 
Flavor is so nicely balanced and full-bodied. Chocolate, dark fruits, roasted coffee and roasted malts, that adds up and gives a nice bitter aftertaste.
Fantastic!

Bottle. Pours black and the head is creamy brown.  Aroma: roasted malt, chocolate and  incredibly coffee. Taste:  Incredible. light sweetness with balanced bitterness. A fabulous beer! I will definitely be grabbing a couple more bottles of this!!!

Pours like dark chocolate milk with a tall lasting head thats rest like a pancake for the duration of the session.Highly aromatic smelling like bitter cocoa and roasted coffee beans. Full and viscous with superb carbonation giving this a creamy mouthfeel. Flavors of roasted coffee intertwined with bitter cocoa with only a touch a sugar. This brew is rich and fattening while retaining sublime sense of balance. The finish leaves a lingering chocolate roasted chestnut essence. Excellent brew.
Bottle. Black colou with a huge brown head. Powerful aroma and taste of coffee, roasted malts, chocolate and dark fruits. Laaasting finish.

Bottle picked up from The Four Firkins yesterday.  Pour was dark black color, with medium champagne like carbonation.  Aroma was rich dark chocolate, espresso, black cherries and pepper.  Flavor is...wow!  Try to imagine the most delicious bitter dark chocolate youve ever had, then imagine taking a sip of the best espresso youve ever had right after eating the chocolate.  Rich and robust flavors of coffee, chocolate, tobacco and a little smooth smoky vanilla on the finish.  Worth the hype, and just amazing.

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2009 Bottle. Thanks to Marsiblursi. Black colour with a minimal brown head. Aroma: Roastiness, coffee, sweetness, dark fruit, charred wood, citrusy hops and peppery alcohol. Taste: Roastiness, coffee, sweet licorice, dark chocolate, light dark fruitiness, coal, citrusy hops, peppery alcohol, dark sugar. Roasted coffee finish. Full bodied and smooth. Re-rated 090513.

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2010 (Bottled) Very dark brown with a small to medium, beige head. Quite delicious aroma with lots of smooth coffee, licorice-roasty malt, and aromatic, American-style hops. Strong and intense, but smooth coffee flavor with lots of roasted malt, some licorice, aromatic hops, milky sourness, and some burned hints in the finish. Hides the ABV completely. Medium to full, velvety-smooth body with low carbonation. An ultra-smooth, yet not too tamed Imperial Stout, a classic. The next 2 bottles were a bit harsh and burned, so dropping the score 4.5 -> 4.2.

Bottle. Pours black with a foamy brown head. Aroma is of rich coffee, dark chocolate, roasted malt, feces, tobacco, and grain. Taste is of gourmet coffee, dark chocolate, roasted malt, tobacco, dark fruit, and smoke. Lingering taste of smoky coffee and wood. Body is thick, almost chunky with flavor. Mouthfeel is extremely thick and very sticky. The flavors in this beer are intense, making this an exceptional drinking expereince. F*ck the hype, this beer is great.

Bottle. My 200th rating, a what a beer to celebrate it with. Pours a deep black colour with nice brown head. Aroma is coffee, malts, roasts, chocolate, dark fruits and oats. The palate is thick, smooth and creamy. The flavor is very well balanced, not that bitter, but more sweet than other Imp. Stouts I have had. Coffee, chocolate, malts, dark chocolate, liquorice. Amazing beer. And as for the weasel ingestion thing, well its definitely a conversation starter, but keep the focus on the beer, and you will not be disappointed.
Bottle.  Pours black with a small head that goes away.  flavors of coffee and dark fruit.  I cant believe how this beer is made! fantastic stout.

300th Rating. 22oz Bottle. Pours Black with a pink ring between the head and the body. Huge 2 finger creamy light brown head with hints of pink in certain light. The head lasts an eternity. The aroma is full of berries and hints of coffee. Flavors of berries, chocolate, caramel and subtle smoke. Wonderful mouth feel. Velvet smooth with just a hint of carbonation. Well balance of sweet to bitter. This was a phenomenal  beer and I am glad I got to share it with Christina, Marco, and Mike.

A pretty careful pour still produces a fat, four-finger thick, darkly browned head in my 25cl tulip glass.  The beer is quite black in color and is opaque even when held up directly to the light.  The aroma smells of darkly roasted grain, wholesome roasted coffee and dark chocolate.  Despite being so roast focused the aroma is quite smooth smelling; it seems to be missing the acrid, sharp burnt notes and charcoal like acidity that plagues many a heavily roasted beer.  Instead the aroma is just rich and quite enjoyable; ample aromas of toasted whole grain bread, roasted berry coffee notes, roasty / toasty whole grain crackers, blackened brown sugar coffee notes and lots of dark, sweet, complex malt character.

Nice and creamy feeling as it first hits the tongue, this beer is fairly viscous, but does have an ample carbonation that contributes a bit more prickly texture than I would prefer; this is easily remedied with some vigorous swirling of my glass.  This beer just tastes incredibly rich and decadent; up front lots of rich cocoa flavors combine with caramelized roast malt notes.  The coffee accentuates a darkly roasted, but not burnt, bright berry flavor here.  It also couples with the dark grain to produce a burnt bitterness in the finish as well as a roast acidity that provides a touch of needed balance to the sweet, chewy malt rather than being harsh.  This beer has such a chewy, dense, rich body to it, it definitely has a syrup like viscosity to it as it rolls across the tongue and clings to the palate.  This beer hides its alcohol extremely well; it is just such a smooth drinking experience.  The roast character can be a touch smoky at times with perhaps a touch of savor, almost salty character to it at times (though it is clearly dominated by the complex malt sugars).

This beer has been quite a nice surprise, I really wasnt expecting this beer to be so smooth and well integrated when I popped the cap; this keeps the typical harsh, bitterly burnt and astringent roast character of both the dark malt and the coffee well in check, and there is a ton of chewy malt character that easily balances what is here.  I almost feel like I should be more critical of this beer than I am, but it is just so tasty, and quite the great experience; if it wasnt fifteen bucks a bottle I would be buying a bunch of this for my beer-fridge; by which I mean drink this now, despite the ample alcohol, I dont see this getting a whole lot better, it is perfect fresh, and I have a feeling any significant age will just make this more unbalanced (though it should still be quite tasty for years to come).

Purchased: Plaza Liquors, Tucson AZ

Flaske: Fantastisk udseende. Stort brunt skumhoved på en kulsort øl. Rigtig god karbonering. Duften af kaffe slår en i møde fra flasken, men efter den er hældt op er der også en del humle og chokolade i duften. Smagen er verdensklasse. Masser af kaffe, chokolade og frugt. Det eneste lille minus er at den er en tand for bitter. Men stadig en fantastisk øl.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2009 Bottle from West Lakeview Liquors in Chicago.   Im not usually in the habit of ingesting something made from something that has previously been ingested by another animal, but if its expensive it must be good.  Pours a viscous very dark opaque brown with a fine fizzy khaki colored head, looks similar to Black Albert.  Very rich strong aroma, a bit of acidity in the coffee, vanilla from the creamy rich oatmeal, super dark high-cocoa chocolate, some decadent dark fruits, smells gritty and chalky.  The aroma is actually quite complex and not really centered on the coffee.  Very tasty, extreme flavor, super dark and bitter, light sugary sweetness,  a bit of dark fruits at first but quickly gets overwhelmed by the coffee, dark bitter-sweet chocolate, lots of acidity from the coffee with just a hint of licorice in the finish.  Really gains complexity as it reaches room temp.  Really long super bitter dark chocolate coffee aftertaste.   Medium bodied with a full mouthful, a bit syrupy and lightly sticky, lots of fine tiny sizzling carbonation that makes the beer feel a bit gritty and fluffy.   A fantastic beer, a complete package. The light fruitiness accenting the dark bitter chocolate and coffee is very decadent.  [So much better at room temp... no stickiness, much fruitier, draws many comparisons to Black Albert]

Celebrating my #500 of the Stouties. It is black, pitch black and the head is dark brown, creamy and lasting. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, licorice and oats  it is incredibly harmonic and extremely inviting. The mouthfeel is fat and nice. The flavour, woow, have I gone to heaven, I must have? It has a light sweetness from the smooth, mellow, perfect amount of oats, and it has a nice present and yet subdued and nicely balanced bitterness, it has notes of coffee, dark and delicious chocolate, licorice and the finish is dry. Just like the Beer Geek Breakfast it is so incredibly clean, strong and very well balanced in all notes.
